name: Martin SCHULZ
text: I declare the session suspended on Wednesday 27 May 2015 to be resumed.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent report, which Before we get into the work, an important clue. Friday of this week marks the 30th anniversary of the signing of the Treaty of Accession of Spain and Portugal to the European Union. This was an important step 30 years ago, because two nations that had suffered decades of dictatorships entered the democratic international community of Europe. Thirty years later, not every promise and desire has been fulfilled. But democracy in these countries has certainly been strengthened and stabilised, and the struggle against the forces of dictatorship and the backward-looking have been won. We are certainly confronted these days – especially when it comes to Spain and Portugal – with doubts about the promises that the European Union makes that prosperity must be combined with welfare for many and not with wealth for the few. I believe that, across all political lines, it is the common will of all Members in this House, beyond all political lines, to ensure, 30 years after this accession, that precisely this promise that the european union's internal market, the political and economic strength of our community – especially after the great sacrifices that the people of Spain and Portugal have made – leads to greater prosperity for many and, above all, to work for young people. , is held by us together.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: The minutes of the meeting of 27 May 2015 have been approved.

name: Emmanouil GLEZOS
text: GUE/NGL). Mr President, I very much regret that I am again obliged to refer to you personally. A moment ago we heard a nice rhetorical speech that corresponded to reality about the dictatorial regimes of Spain and Portugal. But today free Greece, a country that expresses the will of the Greek people to set its own course, is met with fierce opposition on the part of the three institutions, the troika, and on your part, and it strikes me with what right because, as a person you have the right to intervene and say anything, but as President of the European Parliament, I think you do not have the right to express the European Parliament and intervene in Greece and try to strangle it. Take away the hands of all lenders from Greece. Those who think they will subdue the Greek people are fooled.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: The final draft agenda of this part-session, as defined in the Conference of Presidents at its meeting on Thursday 4 June 2015 in accordance with Rule 152 of the Rules of Procedure, has been distributed.  Mr Weber has the floor on the order of business.

name: Manfred WEBER
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which On behalf of the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats, I would like to ask that we deal with the situation in Romania in the next few hours and days. There, an official investigation was launched by the Public Prosecutor's Office against the local head of government, Ponta. Seventeen points have been submitted accusing Mr Ponta. The parliamentary majority of the Socialists in the Romanian Parliament is still blocking the clarification of these 17 tangible points, although Frans Timmermans, the Vice-President responsible for the European Commission, has made it clear that he has great confidence in the investigative authorities in Romania. We in the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats have respect for the sovereign decision of Parliament in Romania. However, we do believe that all citizens expect these allegations to be investigated. In addition, Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the Minister for Justice in Romania has just said that all those who might want to take to the streets and demonstrate are threatened with investigation, and may even be threatened with imprisonment. From the point of view of the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats, it is unacceptable that people are being intimidated there and that the right to demonstrate should be restricted. That is why we in the European Parliament need to talk about this issue. We believe that the LIBE Committee should deal with this and then the European Parliament must also discuss this issue with a resolution. We in the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats are very concerned.

name: Gianni PITTELLA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I have totally different information from mr Weber, at least in the last part of his speech. However, we Socialists agree that this issue can be discussed in the Committee on Civil Liberties, As well as in parliament's ordinary procedure, we do and have done in other cases.  We trust that the debate will take place without partisanship and in the exclusive and honest assessment of the facts. We will not accept either the distortion of the facts or the mortification of a principle that should be of concern to all sincere democrats, which is the presumption of innocence.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Ladies and gentlemen! I now have various speeches. We are discussing the agenda of the plenary and not that of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs. That is why, through the spokespersons of the GROUP of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats and The S&D Group, I have the impression that the majority in this House believes that we should ask the LIBE Committee to look into the matter. That is why I am going to pass this on to Mr Moraes, who asks him to put the issue on the agenda of the next meeting of the LIBE Committee.

name: Rebecca HARMS
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, I would like to thank the In my opinion , even though I have now heard the consensus of the two colleagues , this would be an issue that we should be discussing in the Conference of Presidents, because it is a serious issue. The best way to consult is usually in the Conference of Presidents.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: I am sure we can do that in addition, Mrs Harms. But I also understood the request in such a way that I was asked to refer the matter to the LIBE Committee. That is what I will do. We can still address it – and i am sure you will do so – at the Conference of Presidents on Thursday. (Calls) Well. Before you feel even more offended, we do both. I will put it on the agenda of the Conference of Presidents on Thursday and we will inform the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs. Double stitched holds better. I cannot accept any more requests to speak on this subject. Mr Jurek, do you want to speak on a different subject?

name: Marek JUREK
text: – More than a month ago, ireland held a constitutional referendum on another but similar subject, which introduced a new definition of the family into constitutional provisions. This referendum raises fundamental doubts about the course of his campaign – in a letter to the President we wrote about the fact that funding raises a reservation – the fact that state-funded parties threatened to exclude politicians who were involved on the side that was in the minority in the referendum (...).

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Mr Jurek, I would like to thank Mr Jurek for his We are on the agenda for this plenary session. If you wish to ask for a request for the agenda, you must say so. We are not in a general debate now.

name: Marek JUREK
text: – Fundamental democratic principles have been violated, including, in particular, the principle of the first minority, which is a party that is in a minority in public debate – but should have the same rights. I therefore request that this issue be discussed, that the referendum be held: whether both parties were guaranteed equality in public debate guaranteed by Irish law.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: The following changes have been requested for the draft work plan: Monday: No changes. Tuesday: The S&D Group has requested that Mr Cofferati's report on long-term shareholder involvement and certain elements of the corporate governance statement be postponed until the July part-session and instead present the debate on the Landsbergis report on the state of relations with Russia from Wednesday afternoon to Tuesday morning.

name: Enrique GUERRERO SALOM
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr President, the report named after Mr Cofferati is a relevant report in which there are some substantial points on which there is not yet a firm agreement. There is the possibility of reaching this agreement with a little more time availability and an opening of Mr Cofferati's negotiations with the various groups; and I would ask on behalf of my group to give that time, postponing debate and voting to the next plenary session in July.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: GUE/NGL). Mr President, the GUE/NGL group also believes that it is better to have a little postponement for the July meeting, so that we can discuss this issue more maturity and preparedness, which really matters a great deal. We mustn't rush.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Since no one wishes to speak against the motion, I shall now put Mr Guerrero's request for postponement to the vote. (Parliament adopted the motion) Wednesday: The EFDD Group has requested that the debate on the Lange report on TTIP be continued in the afternoon.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, the reason for this is very simple. In 24 hours, in possibly one of the smallest regions represented in this Parliament, I had over a thousand members of the public contact me about this report. Deputies all over this Chamber have seen that the public care about this issue, and there are actually some quite complex issues that need to be considered and discussed. I do not believe that we can do justice to the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership in under three hours of debate. We have many, many speaking time requests from people within this Group and others across Parliament, so let us show the public that we care too, and give ourselves the chance to subject this report to a little bit more scrutiny.

name: Enrique GUERRERO SALOM
text: – Mr President, well, I am not going to speak exactly against it. What I want is to prevent the vote from taking effect on Wednesday. I mean, if the debate continues in the afternoon, the vote would take place on Thursday.  I am in favour, my group is in favour, that we have more time, and the way to have more time is to advance the debate in the morning, give it more time, that is, instead of starting at 9.00 in the morning, start at 8.00 in the morning.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, we would be happy to start the debate earlier, at 8 a.m.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: We have one thing in common with that. So you want to start at 8 a.m. instead of 9 a.m. The widest possible request is that of the early riser Guerrero. I shall now put this amendment to the vote. (Parliament adopted the motion) The Group of the Greens/European Free Alliance has requested that a resolution be concluded with a resolution on the oral question to the Council on sport and human rights in connection with the European Games in Baku.

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, eight days from now the Baku 2015 European Games will start, in Baku. Since last summer, in Azerbaijan, almost every human rights defender has been put into jail, and we have an oral question on the agenda on Wednesday evening to debate this, but there was no agreement to have a resolution. All the other big institutions that work on human rights – like the Council of Europe across the river there, Nils Muižnieks, Human Rights Commissioner of the Council of Europe, Michel Forst, UN Special Rapporteur on Human Rights Defenders, and Dunja Mijatović, the OSCEʼs Representative on Freedom of the Media – all these have spoken out in writing that sport cannot ignore human rights. So I think that the plenary of this Parliament should not, cannot and must not shy away but should accept our responsibilities and also express ourselves in writing, via a resolution. We need a clear message from here to make sure that people like Leyla Yunus, who was a nominee and shortlisted for the Sakharov Prize last year, and many others, will be freed and that these games will not overshadow the deep and bad human rights situation in Azerbaijan. So I ask you to vote in favour of a resolution.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: Mr President, we are indeed a few days away from the start of the European Games in Baku. President Ilham Aliyev intends to make this event a showcase to restore the image of his regime, which is in great need. There is no doubt that Azerbaijan is an authoritarian regime. And to make the window perfect, human rights defenders are locked up in turn. All NGOs draw our attention to this issue. Whatever our position on sport and human rights, and on the holding of sporting events in countries under such regimes, it is important that we condemn what is currently happening in Azerbaijan. And, as Ms. Lunacek said, I think we are stronger when we speak in writing. Otherwise, I would say it is a debate for laughter. That is why, as coordinator of the GUE/NGL group in the subcommittee on human rights, in which we were unanimous in supporting this issue, I support this request for a resolution from the Green Group.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Mr President, first of all I would like to point out that this matter was raised in the committee responsible, which rejected it and even agreed to have this debate because the majority of the committee responsible said that there should be no resolution. Secondly and most importantly, we had the opportunity a fortnight ago when we were discussing the partnership which is very important, to raise these issues for Azerbaijan, then, so that both the leadership of the European Union and Parliament can raise these issues in time. But that wasn't the raised. Thirdly and also importantly, in twenty days' time there will be a debate in the Council of Europe on this issue, where there is the committee responsible for examining it. I believe that any resolution we decide to have today creates a res judicata and pre-lists the decisions of the competent body which is the Council of Europe. These issues must be taken seriously, as well as the progress of the partnership. So everyone can express themselves here during the debate, but having a resolution does not give all of us time to prepare and debate and the political groups also have their seats to come to the debate in an organised way.

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the I just wanted to ask a question. I have heard that the voting machine did not work for someone from the Liberals. I do not know how he or she would have voted, but if that is the case, it should be noted, whether in favour or against. But, of course, I hope so.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: We will take note of this, as always. However, you know that we have the same problem every time we vote by roll-call or when a vote is checked electronically: colleagues have inserted the card incorrectly, then the machine will not work. I know that. I very much regret that, but I have no other way of doing things than establishing electronic voting. That is why I always ask several times: have everyone voted? This always brings me criticism, because then others say: You wait too long, because you want a certain majority to come out of it. I know all this, but I cannot change it in hindsight. (The order of business has therefore been adopted.)

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the report by Mr Siekierski, on behalf of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development, on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council setting the adjustment rate for direct payments in accordance with Regulation (EU) No. 1306/2013 for direct payments for calendar year 2015 (COM(2015)0141 - C8-0083/2015 - 2015/0070(COD)) (A8-0174/2015).

name: Czesław Adam SIEKIERSKI
text: Rapporteur. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by We are discussing today the adoption of a position on the correction coefficient for direct payments for the calendar year 2015. This is the so-called financial discipline mechanism that was foreseen in the Horizontal Regulation of December 2013 as part of the recent reform of the common agricultural policy. Its main objective is to establish a crisis reserve to support the agricultural sector in the event of major crises affecting agricultural production or the distribution of agricultural products. The total amount of the crisis reserve for the period of the 2014-2020 financial perspective was set at EUR 2.8 billion, which amounts to EUR 400 million per year in 2011 prices. The application of financial discipline to direct payments in 2015 is part of the preparation of the Union budget for 2016, in which the Commission included EUR 441.6 million in current prices in the draft crisis reserve. Following preliminary estimates of direct payments and expenditure related to the agricultural market, the European Commission assumed that an adjustment of direct payments of less than 1.4 per cent would be sufficient.  It should be emphasised here that this reduction will apply only to farmers receiving more than EUR 2 000 in payments per year. Furthermore, due to the investigation of full payments in Bulgaria, Croatia and Romania, financial discipline will not apply to these countries.  According to the Regulation, the weighting should be adopted within the framework of the codecision of the Council and Parliament by 30 June. Therefore, as soon as we received a request from the European Commission in our Committee on Agriculture in Parliament, we decided to apply the simplified and accelerated procedure provided for in Article 50 of the Rules of Procedure, according to which, as chairman of the committee responsible, I drafted the report without amendments after my report was adopted without amendments in the Committee on Agriculture and no amendments were tabled for this plenary session. I hope that in tomorrow's vote we will be able to finally adopt the European Commission's proposal unchanged. With a clear declaration by the Council, which also confirmed in writing its willingness to accept the Commission's proposal without amendments, this will mean that we will be able to reach an agreement at first reading within the time limit set by the regulation. Recent disturbances in Europe's agricultural markets due to the Russian embargo or the expiry of milk quotas show the importance of this crisis reserve. Its importance is further enhanced by the reduction of intervention mechanisms in the reform of the last common agricultural policy, or by the growing influence of external factors, such as the progressive liberalisation of world trade in the context of the profitability of European agriculture and European farmers.  I think that no one in this House needs to be convinced that agriculture is a very sensitive sector, highly dependent on weather, climate conditions, the price situation on world markets, speculation or international events. Therefore, in view of last year's controversy surrounding the agricultural budget, I would like to stress that the agricultural resources that flow back into the agricultural budget should remain there in order to be used to combat the effects of the crisis. I would like to emphasise that this reserve is created from measures that are in the common agricultural policy, farmers freeze them in a sense. We are taking part of the payments so that there are funds for the crisis reserve. If this reserve is not used, then these funds will go back to the farmers, so it can be said that farmers themselves create a reserve.

name: Phil Hogan
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, my brief intervention will not take long. As everybody knows and as was agreed in the CAP reform, the Commission has to propose each year a regulation that fixes the rate of this financial discipline for direct payments. The present proposal for a reduction of 1.393% is needed to finance the crisis reserve in 2016 of EUR 441.6 million. I am pleased that Parliament and the Council are both supporting the proposal, and on that basis I believe we will reach a timely adoption of the proposal, which has been outlined very carefully and very well by the rapporteur, before the end of June.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr President, on the basis that the interests of all citizens of the European Union must be protected in the event of major crisis situations which may be triggered by various factors or situations and which may affect agricultural production or distribution at European level, the European Commission has also launched this year a proposal to adjust direct payments to all farmers. Currently, the rate of adjustment of direct payments is 1.39 % and approves payments for amounts in more than EUR 2 000 per farmer. According to the European executive, that adjustment aims to set up a financing reserve of around EUR 441 million compared to EUR 433 million in the previous year, which can be used in the event of a crisis in the agricultural sector.  Depending on the situation, the European Commission will be able to make a new proposal to adjust the adjustment rate to 1 December 2015, after re-evaluating the forecast in October. The European Parliament must adopt this proposal within the deadline set by the Regulation, i.e. by the end of June, otherwise it is the Commission that will be able to decide the level of this rate. I believe that, as representatives of European citizens, we must respect the deadline.

name: Zbigniew KUŹMIUK
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Speaking on behalf of the ECU faction on a regulation of Parliament and of the Council establishing a correction coefficient for direct payments for the calendar year 2015 and paid in the financial year 2016, I would like to say that my political group supports and will vote in favour of this solution.  The setting of this coefficient, as well as the crisis reserve for the financial year 2016 at EUR 441.6 million in current prices, means that this reserve can be used for agricultural crises. It should be noted that it will be made from direct payments above EUR 2 000 per holding and will not cover three countries where payments are incomplete, i.e. Bulgaria, Romania and Croatia. Although the creation of a correction factor and the creation of a crisis reserve means that the envelopes for national direct payments per EU country are adequately scaled down, we believe that it is appropriate and necessary to create this reserve in such precarious agricultural management conditions. Indeed, the Russian embargo on food products originating in EU countries is ongoing, the situation on many agricultural markets – even on the milk market – is falling the buying-in prices of many agricultural crops, and finally the opening up of EU markets to food imports from third countries is progressing by reducing EU tariffs. All this only increases the risk and uncertainty of agricultural production. I would therefore like to express my hope that the crisis reserve will be used in 2016 to support those farmers and agricultural markets where the situation will be most difficult.

name: Ulrike MÜLLER
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take a iendled with the ALDE Group. Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has The common agricultural policy has developed more and more towards free markets in recent years. The orientation, together with the extensive decoupling of direct payments, and a step towards more entrepreneurial activity by farms have presented major challenges for farms. This orientation also entails higher risks for our farming families, especially for our family farms. These are much more than just production sites for agricultural products. Family farms secure millions of jobs in rural areas and preserve the cultural landscapes in the regions of Europe. The social fabric of the villages can also be preserved only with farms. I am thinking, for example, of the voluntary fire brigades or the many association activities with the farmers. The citizens of the Member States want rural structures and farm products that were created on the basis of family-run agriculture. These are some of the reasons why there can be no market economy without safeguards in this area. We very much welcome the creation of a crisis fund, and this is urgently necessary and right. We have already had this reserve. Modulation funds have been deducted from farmers, but only from a level of EUR 5 000 in direct payments. This margin is now to be reduced. For our farming families, it must be clear what the money is used for and how the funds withheld are actually used. However, the current situation resulting from the Russia embargo also shows that political decisions can create immense market pressure and market distortions. And here, not only money from farming families should be used, but actually also funds from the general budget.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: on behalf of the EPP group. Mr President, I apologise. Many of us had a problem at Strasbourg airport earlier. There was no car.  Commissioner, Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, with this report we are addressing the issue of one of the budgetary constraints of the common agricultural policy, but we are in the area of outright budgetary management. Through this report, of course, as the previous speaker did, we must, as the previous speaker did, mention the problem of the Russian embargo and its possible future impact on this mechanism.  We have already had the opportunity to ask ourselves about this in the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development: is it normal that farmers, victims in all markets and throughout the year of a crisis first of diplomatic origin, are still harmed the following year at the time of the regulation of aid? You have nothing to do with it, Commissioner, and it is not you who are implicated in this case. But it is indeed a show of solidarity on the part of the whole college, but also on the part of all the European institutions, that farmers are entitled to expect, and we ask you, Commissioner, to be the spokesperson.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, we share the need to set up a fund for crisis situations, but we also believe that clear criteria need to be established to know when such crisis situations occur. Current agricultural policy causes ongoing and ongoing crises in the production sectors. Right now, in many countries of the European Union - including Galicia, my country - milk producers have hit bottom: prices below production costs, companies that have large milk defaults. That is why, Commissioner, we think that it is necessary to act already, with financial support, but also by initiating the process for a public dairy policy that avoids these situations. On the other hand, we believe that crises caused by erroneous decisions by the European Union, such as those that led us to the situation of the Russian veto, should be financed by other funds and not with the support of this reserve, which is of farmers and farmers.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would first like to welcome the presence among us of a group from Burgundy, a great French agricultural and wine region, with names that smell good about France, such as Pouilly-Fuissé, Chambolle-Musigny or other Meursault. Mr President, Commissioner, this is a serious time: the European Union is currently pursuing a suicidal policy in the agricultural field. Schulz and his friends at the European Commission have adopted sanctions against Russia. However, it is now an entire continent that is being held hostage in the name of political considerations. In exchange, farmers are doubly victimized. On the one hand, they are victims of this Russian embargo, which has cost so far, just for France - just for France, listen to me - a billion euros. On the other hand, the European Union has drawn from the common agricultural policy to finance this fund to help European farmers.  Today we want a concrete answer: where is the European Union in the negotiations to lift sanctions, so as to keep European and French farmers alive and give some oxygen?

name: Esther HERRANZ GARCÍA
text: – Mr President, first of all I would like to congratulate Mr Siekierski on his work as rapporteur in this report and, secondly, also to congratulate the Commissioner, as a representative of the European Commission, on his proposal, on a proposal which keeps the crisis reserve created in the latest reform of the common agricultural policy stable.  The aim of the creation of this instrument is to have funds to deal with the market crisis where significant. However, this reserve is set at EUR 442 million; it is an added effort for European producers, who see their direct aid reduced to cover market eventualities which could often be covered by using the budgetary margin - as long as we do not continue to scratch funds from that margin to finance projects outside of strict agricultural spending. The reserve has not been used until now and, in the future, it must be avoided to deal with critical situations caused by causes outside the agricultural sector. This was the case with the embargo decreed by Russia, since 7 August last year. The Commission's immediate reaction was to take over the reserve, but fortunately the majority response was contrary to that measure, which would have made our farmers and ranchers 'head of The Turk' of a political decision for which they had no responsibility.  I am of the opinion that this crisis should have been financed even with funds totally outside the agricultural budget. The veto is not over and I would like to ask the Commission today what assurances we have that the agricultural reserve will not be used in the event that the Russian embargo extends beyond the summer. I believe that the reserve must, for the time being, remain untouchable and always ready to allow, if necessary, a rapid and effective response by Europe to any eventuality that occurs as a result of the intrinsic evolution of agricultural markets - but of agricultural markets. And so I think we should try to make more effective and efficient management of available resources.

name: Paul BRANNEN
text: – Mr President, the annual exercise to establish the reserve for crises in the agricultural sector helps ensure that farmers’ incomes are protected in the event of natural disasters and price volatility. The reserve for crises should be considered as one element of a safety net which guards against the elements that farmers cannot normally anticipate. The crisis reserve is financed out of the envelope available for direct payments in the given year. This is a fair provision which takes into account that the EU budget, already strained in times of economic hardship, should not accommodate additional spending in case of an emergency in the sector. The functioning of the crisis reserve is surely a good opportunity to look more closely at the risk management potential of the CAP, which should pay more attention to providing solutions to potential future problems. Instead of concentrating on income support, we should make more use of the funds intentionally set aside in order to manage the detrimental effects of natural disasters, outbreaks of disease or trade embargoes. The CAP budget is surely big enough to respond to the needs of the sector. It is all about allocating these resources carefully, wisely and prudently.

name: Janusz WOJCIECHOWSKI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by The great European value is solidarity – the principle that one for all, all for one. In the name of this solidarity, sanctions on trade with Russia have been established, because that is what Europe's security requires, because it required a firm opposition to Russian expansion, a threat to peace in Europe. On the other hand, this principle of solidarity has not worked or has worked very poorly, because it is farmers who have suffered the economic consequences of these sanctions. A farmer in Finland, the Baltic states or Poland, farmers who could not sell their milk or their apples (in the case of Polish it was a real drama, because one million tonnes of apples had previously been exported to Russia and this was stopped), also farmers of other countries, France or Germany, suffered heavy losses – these were losses of several billion euros, and the aid , which farmers received, were only hundreds of millions of euros, and this is still unfairly, not always reasonably divided. It is a great pity that this fund, which is set up every year in the event of a crisis, has not been used for this purpose. The question arises as to why this fund is at all, since it has not been used in such a situation as arose in connection with the Russian embargo. I call for this fund to be managed wisely in the future and to be used in such situations.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: – Mr. President, Dear Mr. Commissioner and Dear Mr. Rapporteur, I want to make it very clear right from the outset that I strongly support the establishment of such a crisis fund because I am convinced that it is very necessary for our farmers today.  It is not only a question of this current situation with Russia that should encourage us to have an appropriate crisis fund, but precisely the global situation on the world market and the need to protect our farmers who are increasingly facing the world market with extremely big challenges. That's why I'm sure, Dear Mr. Rapporteur and Respected Commissioner, that this is a good path for a motion in this case.  The creation of such a single fund will provide one additional certainty and of course, as already stated, and a kind of solidarity between us in Europe which is absolutely necessary, which is in fact at the foundation of the European Union. When we talk about the fact that the country from which I come, Croatia, will not be included in this program, but is predicted to be only in 2022, I would not want it to create one situation that would be very unpleasant for our farmers from Croatia, i.e. from Bulgaria and Romania, because they will supposedly be included only next year, but still next year , and Croatia only in 2022.  We need to send a clear message that these producers of agricultural products will also have the opportunity to come and enter the door of the Solidarity Fund and the agricultural fund, as they too face a Russian embargo, such as the export of mandarins from the Neretva Valley or face the problems of overall placement on the world market of various agricultural products. That is why I invite you to think very carefully about how we will really include Croatian producers of agricultural products in the use of this fund.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: – Mr President, I support this idea of a reserve to help farmers, but I think it is a bit sad that the European Union has decided to become the world’s policeman and has sent that bill to the farmers of Europe. As far as I can see, it is not working. It is all right to say that we must do something – anything – just for the sake of it, but when it costs farmers to the tune of EUR 235 million in Ireland and costs hundreds of millions all around Europe, it is hard to know what has been achieved. It should be saved for a real crisis. We already have a reserve in Ireland under the common agricultural policy, and that is 80% of the common agricultural policy’s funding – reserved for the richest farmers, because they are the ones who, supposedly, must be protected. But to the small family farm in my country, goodbye: this emergency fund will not help them.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: – Mr President, direct payments are the absolutely indispensable mechanism for sustainable and efficient agriculture. That is why I welcome the concern of the Commission in general and Commissioner Phil Hogan in particular to always refer to the realities on the ground designed to provide an opportunity to take the best measures for the agricultural sector. In this respect, the adjustment rate should be offered to apply only to the amount of direct payments for which aid applications were submitted in 2015, without taking into account the time when payments were made to farmers, precisely as Member States have the possibility to make late payments after that payment period within a certain time limit. However, I would like to draw attention to the inadmissible differences between direct payments between Member States today, with all the responsibility and all due respect to the European institutions, to the inadmissible differences between direct payments between Member States, which creates major imbalances. Never can a subsidy of EUR 150 received by a Romanian farmer be equal to a subsidy of EUR 700-800 as a farmer from another State receives on the same unit of measure, which seems to me to be profoundly incorrect. The Commission must therefore ensure, in the future, that the differences between farmers in the European Union are eliminated, ensuring equal treatment, with the obligation, however, to take account of the particularities of each area as a consequence of membership of the single European area. Last but not least, the Commission must continue to be concerned about the need to strike, on the one hand, a balance between supporting the performance achieved by farmers and, on the other hand, affordable and cheap food for all the inhabitants of the European Union and beyond. The embargo imposed on Russia, the lack of sufficiently strong markets to absorb all agricultural production at Union level, highlights the need for a joint effort by all responsible factors to find viable solutions in crisis situations.

name: Jean-Paul DENANOT
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the regulatory question of the arbitrary rate of 1.34 for 2016 seems reasonable in terms of the elements at our disposal.  In fact, the issue is not the definition of rates, but the budgetary question of margins in terms of appropriations. I have already highlighted this aspect in the report for opinion on the 2016 budget, which I drafted under the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development. In the course of 2016, in the event of a major crisis, the ceiling margins available in heading 2 should be used as a priority in terms of commitment appropriations for the 2016 budget. As has already been said on several occasions, crises in the agricultural sector are likely to increase, particularly in view of Russia's attitude towards Ukraine. Non-compliance with the Minsk agreements is in everyone's minds. I believe that funds should be guaranteed to farmers, who are doubly affected by the Russian embargo. For fruits and vegetables, the situation can quickly become critical throughout the country. Not to mention the issue of the abolition of milk quotas, which risks jeopardising many small farms in France and all European countries.

name: Richard ASHWORTH
text: – Mr President, I appreciate and understand the intent of a solidarity crisis reserve. However, this Group did not support it at the outset: we felt that there might be a better, more equitable way to fund this provision. I have no problem with the lowering of the threshold for contributions, but rather I must express my concerns about the impact on producers in my own country. It is a country which, because of its farm structure, has fewer larger farms than most of the other countries in the European Union. That means individual producers – producers who are already hard pressed – will carry a greater burden of cost than average farmers. This is a contribution towards a fund which, historically, their own government has declined to access.

name: Nedzhmi ALI
text: – Mr President, implementing the requirements set out in the regulation on the financing, management and monitoring of the common agricultural policy and establishing rules for direct payments to farmers under support schemes is an important element in the process of drawing up the 2016 EU budget. According to the regulations, in order to support the agricultural sector in case of major crises affecting agricultural production or distribution, the reserve for crises which is proposed by the Commission to be included in the 2016 draft budget is EUR 441.6 million. The percentage of the financial discipline adjustment rate – approximately 1.39%, which we hope is calculated correctly – is based on the presumption that it will be applied only to the amount of direct payments for farmers which exceed EUR 2 000 and does not include three Member States. In this regard, the financial discipline adjustment rate means less money for the farmers and, in this context, it will be a good step to do the maximum for the simplification of the application forms for small farmers. The above-mentioned sum will be included in the 2016 draft budget, with the budget heading ‘reserve for crises’. Regarding the correct implementation of the requirements, we support the report for fixing the adjustment rate for direct payments in respect of the 2015 calendar.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: – Mr President, small farmers in southern Europe have been living in a state of permanent crisis for years. Do you know how much the Asturian farmers, the people of my land, the litre of milk, have had to sell? 33 months. Of course it's okay and it's pertinent to create a crisis fund, but please don't pat each other on the back. Such measures are not sufficient. You can't cover the sun with one finger. One farmer told me a few months ago: "I don't want handouts: I want to have some tool to be able to influence, at least a little, the price of the product I sell; I want to work and live with dignity." Welcome to all actions aimed at rescuing people at a timely time of crisis, but it is urgent to put all our political will into building, once and for all, a productive model that protects the common good, where the land and the people who work it are the center, not the particular interests of large corporations. Let us think of the people to which we owe ourselves and who suffer the consequences of the wrong decisions made. Political responsibility, height of view: we owe it to the public.

name: Annie SCHREIJER-PIERIK
text: Firstly, I would like to say that I fully support the rapporteur's proposal, because the boycott by Russia has hit the exports of European agricultural and horticultural products hard and this problem is still on the table. Exports of Dutch products to Russia have decreased by more than 30% this year.  Eu financial support has therefore been of great importance in the past year for many family farms, but also for related sectors. Because it's hard to keep your head above water. Nevertheless, most of the money has gone to the fruit and vegetable sector - that is good - and to the dairy sector, but we also have other sectors. The pig farming sector has certainly been hit very hard by the boycott in the Netherlands. Crisis funds should benefit all sectors and it should also be clarified how these crisis funds can be used. Smaller sectors often have a lot of difficulty with this.  I also call for the use of all the resources available in the future from the crisis pot. After all, we all know that the unused funds flow back to arable land and dairy farmers. There's nothing wrong with that, but people still need the money. And I would ask the Commissioner - whatever I have done in committee - to postpone and to postpone the deadline from June to 7 August. Then we can also look at the national envelopes and help the sectors that are still in crisis today. After all, the season is still in full swing. If you look at the prices, especially for tomatoes, this will certainly be used.  And finally, one point is important. We are in favour of a Europe of fewer rules. I always notice from our farmers and gardeners that people do not know how these rules can be used in difficult times. Nevertheless, this is often what a farming company can do.

name: Laurenţiu REBEGA
text: – Mr President, it is obvious that we need such a crisis instrument to use money in the interests of farmers, but at the same time we must consider the following: it is important to use the money in the right directions to help farmers when they need it. That is why, unfortunately, no one can predict or predict the start of a crisis as we had the embargo in Russia. That is why I think it is important that the Commission, and I have great confidence in Commissioner Hogan, that it will set some extremely clear conditions for the beneficiaries of these funds. Let us not forget that they are actually the contributors to this reserve fund and, on the other hand, as my other colleagues said, let us not forget that it is almost impossible to have farmers compete with each other given the differences they receive as amounts of money. So I stress once again that full alignment of direct payments to farmers should be ensured as soon as possible.

name: Jørn DOHRMANN
text: Mr President! Commissioner! Ladies and gentlemen! We know that agriculture suffers in all countries. I think it is important that we can work together to safeguard the interests of agriculture. Unfortunately, as we all know, 2016 will also be a potentially difficult year for agriculture because of producers, because of Russia's embargo on EU agricultural products. This means job losses, and we must think about it, and that is why we must also help to help agriculture. This is why some relief is needed, including for farmers, who are paying a high price for the crisis and for the possible crisis that is in agriculture all around. It remains to be seen how long and whether the Russian embargo will continue. One thing is certain, however, namely that it is farmers who are paying the price for the political disputes between the EUROPEAN Union and Russia. Therefore, new markets must be found for the products that would normally have been shipped to Russia, as Russia was an important market for EU products. As you all know, the export of pork is one of Denmark's products, which is very hard hit, so there must be alternative markets.

name: João FERREIRA
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, the need for a crisis reserve is not at issue. But rather the fact that this CAP is itself a permanent factor of crisis. The latest reform has maintained scandalous inequalities in the distribution of CAP funds between countries, producers and producers. Liberalisation and market orientation is the watchword. Millions of small and medium-sized farmers know the meaning of these words: prices that do not compensate for production, ruin of millions of farms, concentration of production, increased food dependence in several countries. Competitiveness is another watchword, but some receive double or triple the payments per hectare allocated to others. So it's easy to be competitive! In Portugal, many thousands of small and medium-sized farmers struggle to survive, to stay in business, with production prices that often do not cover production costs. For them, it is not the meagre five hundred euros, I stress, five hundred euros, which will receive a single payment that will end the crisis.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, in the context of the last cap reform, European farmers have been subject to financial discipline with the aim of establishing a reserve fund that allows, in the event of a sharp and prolonged crisis in production and markets, the Commission to intervene. I welcome the Commission's proposal, as it safeguards small producers by exempting direct payments below EUR 2 000 from the application of the fee. Already last year this occurred and at the end of the year we were debating what to do with the surplus in the heading related to agriculture, with very strong positions on both sides, in which some wanted it to be absorbed into the Commission's overall budget and many argued that it should be reinvested in the sector. We cannot continue to pass this message on to our producers, because if there is some kind of financial surplus in the sector it should be used to avoid cutting direct payments to farmers in the following year. Commissioner, although this measure is included in the CAP regulation, extraordinary situations require extraordinary decisions. European farmers are exposed to a number of risk factors that jeopardise their activity and income. I am talking about the Russian embargo which, despite the commission's timely and timely interventions, has caused a serious crisis in the sector, which we are still feeling. I am talking about the impact of the end of dairy quotas; we are still in an adjustment phase, but the loss of income in certain regions, such as the outermost regions, has been accentuated.  The Russian embargo is an example of how a political and diplomatic decision was a direct economic sanction to our agricultural producers. As this crisis did not originate in the sector, I believe that all commission interventions to continue to mitigate the negative impacts of this situation do not go away from this heading. I also believe that part of this money should be allocated to the Milk Observatory, with more and better skills and instruments for market intervention and regulation, so that it can effectively intervene in the milk market, which runs through many European regions, such as the outermost regions, a serious crisis that needs to mitigate. Finally, I would also ask that producers in the outermost regions be exempted from this financial discipline or at least to increase the level of exemption given the enormous constraints they are experiencing, in particular the opening up of new markets and the crises I have mentioned above.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: – Mr President, I would like to express my positive vote for the fixing of an adjustment rate for direct payments in 2015. This will provide a reserve that will allow additional support for the agricultural sector in the case of a natural crisis affecting agricultural production or distribution, by applying, at the beginning of each year, a reduction to direct payments with a financial discipline mechanism. Even if I truly hope that the crisis reserve will not be needed, I believe that, if such an event happens, it will be an important means for the European agricultural sector, from which we will all benefit. Also, I am strongly in favour of very clear conditions being imposed for beneficiaries. I thank the rapporteur and the shadow rapporteurs.

name: Daniel DALTON
text: – Mr President, I did not support setting up the crisis reserve as part of the common agricultural policy reform. I see it as more of the same old approach to agriculture policy. There are many other measures available to the Commission before it needs to top-slice money from certain farmers in certain Member States. More money is not always the answer. A better, more flexible and more liberal CAP, which allows farmers to be globally competitive, is the answer to crises and will stop them having an effect in the future. However, my real problem with this is the unfairness of the funding measures. A threshold of EUR 2 000 means that Member States with the largest farms will contribute the most. Three Member States will not contribute at all. I do not see that as solidarity. If we are going to have a crisis reserve – and, as I say, I do not think we should – all farmers should contribute. Otherwise, this looks like a money grab from some Member States to others. This is certainly how UK farmers will see it, as they are being asked to fund disproportionately a crisis reserve that they are unlikely ever to benefit from.

name: Elisabeth KÖSTINGER
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his excellent work and for the work she has done. I see the situation somewhat differently from Mr Dalton. I believe that the Russia embargo was by no means caused by the farmers and that we have the task of intervening in this area. And I believe that this embargo also shows how important the crisis reserve in the agricultural sector is. Across Europe, for example, these special measures have really significantly relieved the fruit and vegetable market. For Austria, for example, this means additional funds of EUR 100 000 for export measures to third countries, which do indeed relieve the markets very much and thus also help farmers. And I think that these are important measures in times of crisis. However, and I would like to make this very clear, we are still very much in need of more work to be done here. Communication, for example in the case of immediate measures, needs to be significantly improved. Above all, we need a lean and efficient settlement system. Aid in times of crisis must not become a skewering run for farmers and more bureaucracy. I would really like to ask the Commission to present a comprehensive evaluation of the extraordinary special measures. We must not wait for the next crisis to improve the instruments and, for example, to present EU-wide approaches to crisis management, including an adequate budget. Finally, like my colleague Sofia Ribeiro, I would like to draw attention once again to the dairy sector. On 31 March, the milk quota expired throughout Europe, and this poses very great challenges, especially for our dairy farmers in mountain areas and, she mentioned this, also in less-favoured areas and in the outermost regions. The winding-up of the super levy in the next quota year will once again deprive the dairy sector of considerable resources. Commissioner, I would really ask you to make every effort to ensure that these measures and revenue from the super levy are used to strengthen the competitiveness of the dairy sector.

name: Paolo DE CASTRO
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the regulation we will be voting on tomorrow consists of the approval of financial discipline: a mathematical calculation made by the Commission which, in order to constitute the crisis reserve for the 2016 budget, sets a rate of reduction in direct payments for 2015. Our group will vote in favour of mr Siekierski's draft report, which we approved in the Committee on Agriculture under the simplified procedure. However, this debate gives us the opportunity to emphasise that the mechanism of financial discipline is the result of a reduction in the agricultural budget decided with the 2014-2020 Financial Perspective, which have left the agricultural budget with no room to respond to crises. But crises, as has been said, are becoming more and more frequent – and as demonstrated by the russian embargo – and, in addition, prices are suffering from increasing volatility. It is the farmers themselves, through the reduction of the first pillar of the CAP, who have to pay for these crises. From a long-term perspective, Commissioner, we must therefore rethink the crisis management instruments, new and stronger instruments that can represent a safety net for farmers and thus make them compete without fear in the global market. Finally, Commissioner, in the last parliamentary term, Parliament argued that financial discipline should only apply to farmers receiving more than EUR 5 000, in order to be able to provide greater protection for small farmers. Unfortunately, in the final agreement, the threshold was then set at EUR 2 000. We still think that a higher threshold would be a fairer way, which would make it possible not to reduce payments to small farmers, and would only charge those for whom a small reduction in their CAP payment does not have an excessively negative impact.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Mr President, Commissioner, at a time when Draghi has EUR 1.1 trillion to buy private and public debt, the amount of four hundred and forty-one million euros of the reserve for dealing with crises in the agricultural sector is crumbs for farmers in Greece and the rest of southern Europe, who are affected by the Russian embargo and have so far lost hundreds of millions of euros.  The poor Greek farmers have also been tested this year by the disasters in their production, due to the natural disasters that have hit my country. At the same time, the tax raid experienced by Greek farmers this year, at the behest of the troika, has been illegally extended to the Community aid they receive. Thus, over the last five years, the income of Greek farmers has fallen by one and a half billion euros and the taxes paid have increased by 150%.  For these reasons, the rate of adjustment, i.e. the rate of reduction laid down in the regulation under discussion, should not apply to aid granted to Greek farmers, since if Greek farmers do not opt out this will lead to a further unfair reduction in their incomes.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: – Mr. President, quality budget planning is one of the most difficult tasks of responsible management and business of any organization. The budget planning of the European Union depends on the advantage that the 28 Member States of the Union have globally, depending on the quality of life of half a billion of its citizens. The planning of the agricultural budget for 2016 under the Multiannual Financial Framework, which is one of the most complex mechanisms of the European Union, regulated on the basis of the Common Agricultural Policy, requires planning and adequate reserves for cases of major crises in the sector. The amount of the agricultural crisis reserve, to be included in the Commission's draft budget for 2016, is €441.6 million. This will come from direct payments to farmers exceeding €2,000. A 1.39% reduction in aid to be set by this Regulation will not apply to payments to farmers in Croatia, Romania and Bulgaria. European agriculture faces losses caused by political decisions that led to the Russian embargo. Farmers are not responsible for this crisis. I therefore consider that compensation for farmers should not be paid from the agriculture budget. These losses must be recovered from other sources, while the reserve we are discussing today should be saved for crises for which funds are foreseen and which have their causes in the agricultural sector.  I therefore call on the European Commission to ensure from its reserve the indemnity for milk, apple and mandarin producers, which have suffered heavy losses due to the Russian embargo for the second year in a row.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: – As my fellow group members have already indicated, I join in making adjustment rates and reserve numbers for crises affecting the agricultural sector acceptable, as reported by the Commission, and I fully recognise its professional merits.  However, I would like to draw the Commission's attention to the fact that one of the terrible signs of maladministration in Hungary in practice is that direct payments and various damage funds are now increasingly migrating to friends of pro-government politicians, oligarchs and ministers in Hungary. In many cases, it's unbeatable, although obviously a corrupt government takes care of it. So there are growing conflicts of interest, and there is little consolation that two very important leaders of the Hungarian Agricultural Office, which is awarding these subsidies, were arrested the other day, and that 100% of the time, only oligarchs are available for the lease of public lands, in Hungarian the Hungarian people see that the Union supports this land theft. The opposition has said this on numerous occasions. In any case, I welcome the Commission's decision to treat as public data from 31 May this year who has taken on what support.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Thank you, Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in order to support the agricultural sector in the event of serious crises affecting agricultural production or the distribution of agricultural products, the establishment of a reserve is of the utmost importance. It is a political duty to equip ourselves with effective instruments to combat emergency situations, which today unfortunately represent more of the norm than the exception in the agricultural sector. This sector is being put to the test by the Russian embargo and the end of milk quotas and which is heavily dependent on unpredictable factors, such as the climate, the effects of globalisation and international crises.  The amount of the reserve for crises in the agricultural sector, which is expected to be included in the Commission's draft 2016 budget, amounts to EUR 441.6 million at current prices. I hope that if the amount is not used, it will be returned to farmers in the form of a direct payment.  This is not a solution for the sector, of course: the world of agriculture is paying for its own crises, but I hope that the Commission, Commissioner Hogan, whose initiatives I welcome, will be able to find the right solutions in the medium term.

name: John Stuart AGNEW
text: – Mr President, the one point we are all clear about is that there is a lack of clarity as to the rules for the disbursement of this fund. But I can make a suggestion here, and I see Commissioner Hogan is turning round to have a look at me – well, I am rather flattered: thank you very much. British farmers are sustaining a 15% pay cut due to the weakness of the euro. Why is the euro so weak? Because it is being used by countries which never should have been allowed to join a single currency in the first place. This may not constitute an act of God, which is what the fund should be used for, but it is an act of the Commission – an institution that has assumed the mantle of deity and can accordingly be included in this definition. This fund could therefore be used as a replacement for what used to be called the ‘green pound’. This would help to offset the sharp drop in direct payments to British farmers and go a small way to compensating for loss of export opportunities and the undercutting of their domestic price by cheap eurozone imports. This is not an argument for the UK itself to join the euro, and I am sure that is what you will try and convince us to do, Commissioner – but, had we done so, British taxpayers would be impoverished to the extent that they would struggle to finance the CAP at all. It is convenient for Member States to forget that the UK is a massive net contributor to the CAP, and our taxpayers should have the comfort of knowing that their money is at least being used to support domestic agriculture and local food, as opposed to propping up a failed economic project. Commissioner, I will stay on in the debate as long as I can – but I have to go to an agricultural meeting, as you know – because I would like to hear what you have got to say about all of that.

name: Emmanouil GLEZOS
text: GUE/NGL). Mr President, let us not ostrich and let us not throw the cause of the situation of our farmers into the Russian embargo. Before the Russian embargo there was the European Union embargo. Who's the one who's been the one who's been the one who's The European Union was the first to come, and there is no doubt that it is useful. There must be a fund to deal with the natural disasters, but especially for Greece I would like to note the fact that, apart from the economic crisis, which was not caused by the Greek farmers, nor by the Greek people, the policy of the institutions towards our rural economy is terrible.  They do not want the rural economy to grow in Greece. They don't want us either industrial country, they don't want us to exploit the mild and renewable energy sources, they want us a resort, a big hotel they want Greece!

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: – Honourable President, honourable colleagues, thank you for the floor.  I therefore support this regulation on the adjustment rate of payments for 2015 to be paid in 2016, and the fact is, even in this case, if we want to give something, we also need to take something from another source, and all the more necessary, of course, adequate control over the use of these funds.  This appropriation will also be used to weaken the consequences of the crisis, and I therefore consider it extremely important that we have a clear eye on what criteria the Commission will use to allocate these funds, that these criteria are properly and fairly valued and that, of course, control of these funds is also defined. That we do not get into a situation where, of course, we will be able to talk about irregularities here in Parliament later, so we would like to draw particular attention to both the performance and the regularity of the use of these funds, even if it is a crisis issue.

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: – Mr President, the fact is that crises and market difficulties occur in real places to real people. Even if emergency funds are needed (and they may be), they should be managed and used at a local level. This is another area where, even if the idea makes sense – emergencies happen, help is needed – it should be implemented at Member State and local level. Our Irish colleague was right earlier: Member States have the solution. We should not be trying to do it for the entire 500 million population stretching from Arctic tundra, through Shropshire dairy farms to Sicilian olive groves. When will the EU understand that big is bad, small is beautiful and micro is magic? Bring it down to the local level: that is what we want.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: - Dear Commissioner for Agriculture, On a specific, very important matter, I would like to ask for your urgent assistance, response and investigation. I was in the famous Hungarian wilderness, the Hortobágy National Park, at the end of the week, and I experienced very shocking things that I would like to share with you and my fellow Members. You go about 15 kilometers by car without seeing a single grazing animal in the famous pastures of the wild. Why aren't there any animals? Because the animals are locked in stables and hodses, because livestock farmers have lost pasture land in corrupt public land applications, the animals cannot graze. Animal health is being ruined, farmers and farms are being destroyed because they have won over pastures by people who, and you will see this with a good eye on the land, do not graze, they do not have animals, they do not have a need for land, they just want money, they want nothing more than eu hectare-based subsidies. I'd like you to investigate this matter as a matter of urgency. Thank you!

name: Phil Hogan
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I want to thank all of the Members who contributed to this debate, and in particular I would like to thank Mr Siekierski, the rapporteur, for bringing forward this report tonight. I want to commend the last common agricultural policy reform, and the people associated with approving it, for providing a crisis reserve without requiring additional finance to be provided for agriculture. This, in essence, shows the solidarity of the European Union with the farming community at times of crisis. I welcome the support shown here today for the proposal which will establish this reserve for 2015 for the benefit of farmers in particular difficulties. The crisis reserve is solidarity in action. After all, as I said, it is funded from the existing resources of the farming community. Many Members raised the Russian ban and its consequences for European farmers. I want to remind you that, last October, the Commission had a proposal which would have utilised the crisis reserve of EUR 433 million for that particular foreign policy decision. In November the new Commission was in a position to reverse that decision and to provide from other sources the resources necessary to show solidarity with the farming community at times of difficulty, arising from the Russian ban. If fully drawn down, these measures will cost EUR 350 million, without reference to the crisis reserve. Members like Mr Dantin who made considerable representations on these matters will, of course, recall these particular measures very well. But I know that many Members have forgotten these particular decisions that were made in November in order to counter the concerns of many members of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development (AGRI) at that time. I wish to thank Budget Commissioner Georgieva for being very sympathetic to providing that positive outcome for European farmers at a difficult time. I would say to Ms Schreijer-Pierik, in relation to pigmeat, that I opened Aids to Private Storage in order to recognise the difficulties for pigmeat producers in many Member States. This scheme was open for about 10 weeks. It provided a withdrawal from the market of a significant tonnage from the pigmeat sector, and it has certainly stabilised incomes for many pigmeat producers. I also provided an opportunity for additional promotion measures for the pigmeat sector to replace some of the market share that was going to Russia, particularly in countries like the Philippines in the Far East, which now account for 73% of the products in the pigmeat sector that had been going to Russia. So the market-orientated policy that you have voted for and supported is working in action in relation to how we are dealing with the pigmeat sector. In terms of the application of financial discipline adjustment, it is important to remind ourselves that small farmers throughout the EU are exempted by the application of the EUR 2000 threshold, below which the adjustment rate does not apply. I know that when Mr Ashworth said earlier that, because of their farm structure, a lot of farmers in the UK – and indeed in other Member States – would not have to pay this particular contribution, he was certainly reflecting the reality of the fact that larger and medium-sized producers are the ones in a better position to pay for this particular instrument. Mr Agnew made another very valuable contribution with regard to the UK staying in Europe, because he will know better than anybody that looking for EUR 25 billion – which is the amount of money that the European Union is subsidising British farmers at the moment – will be very difficult when you are competing with the public services around the Cabinet table of a UK government. The EU is quite generous to British farmers – and rightly so – in addition to all of the other farmers in the Union. I would subscribe to the view that the EU will always be more supportive of agriculture and rural development measures in the UK than its own government is. I want to conclude by repeating my welcome for the proposal, and I look forward to a positive vote tomorrow.

name: Czesław Adam SIEKIERSKI
text: Rapporteur. – This report is formal and technical and the discussion was very substantive, which I would like to emphasise and thank you for. The accelerated procedure for the adoption of this document means a high degree of agreement between the Council, Parliament and the Commission, which is worth highlighting in these responses to needs or in difficult situations. There was talk of solidarity, because in fact almost everyone, with the exception of the smallest ones, is consisting of almost everyone, and these farmers, who are affected by a difficult crisis, are benefiting from this aid. This solidarity is therefore extremely important. Let us remember that agriculture has its own peculiarities: it depends on climatic, weather, external conditions. At the moment, there is still a very clear dependence on the international situation. Hence the need for certain instruments that are not always able to generate a free market.  The free market requires some support to address these agricultural emergencies. Let us also remember that the great weakness of the reform of the common agricultural policy, which we are implementing at the moment, is precisely the reduction in forms of intervention on agricultural markets. I have spoken about the advisability of these interventions, and in this limitation we have gone too far. That is why it is important to manage the market well – because we have less money at the moment for the CAP at the moment, less money for agricultural matters. I think we cannot say such things that the CAP is leading to a crisis. The CAP supports agriculture and supports consumers – because this means that support for agriculture is cheaper for food and therefore consumers pay less for the products they buy. Finally, I would like to thank the Presidency and once again the Commission for its cooperation.

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Tuesday, 9 June 2015. Written declarations (Article 162 OF the CRP)

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. –  These matters should never be dealt with at European Union level. I am not opposed to the principle of having appropriate contingency funds, but I do believe that countries could enact such a scheme directly themselves with far less bureaucracy, and at a much more appropriate level.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: Writing. – The European Commission plans to transfer EUR 441.6 million from the direct agricultural aid budget to the Agricultural Crisis Fund at current prices by 2016. The withdrawal adjustment rate will be approximately 1.4%. This withdrawal of 1.4% is not significant and will not hit farmers. I welcome the fact that the European Commission has decided on a sufficiently moderate withdrawal. Unfortunately, this has not always been the case. One of the barroso commission's last measures last autumn would have been a significant curtailment of this year's farmers' subsidies. Fortunately, this plan has not been carried through because of the decisive action taken by the European Parliament and the Council. In this work, my fellow Member Tamás Deutsch and I have taken a lion's share in Parliament. The financial withdrawal under the current proposal will therefore not hit farmers, so I will support it with a calm heart.

name: Beata GOSIEWSKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Agriculture as one of the most vulnerable sectors of the economy requires special protection. Setting a crisis reserve of €441.6 million is essential to protect the interests of farmers in the EU. The current geopolitical situation in Europe and the resulting direct collapse in agricultural product markets have shown an imperfection in the current emergency response legislation. The introduction of a Russian embargo on agricultural products from EU countries, the ever-falling purchase prices of agricultural crops, and the opening up of EU markets to food imports from third countries through reductions in EU tariffs all show the increasing risks and uncertainties of farming in the agricultural sector.  I believe that the report of the Committee on Agriculture on the correction coefficient for direct payments for 2015 should be adopted, as the creation of a crisis reserve during the period of uneasy European agricultural economy is absolutely necessary. This reserve is intended to protect European agriculture and to give the European farmer a sense of at least relative security.

name: Jarosław KALINOWSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The correction factor for direct payments for 2015 concerns the establishment of a reserve to support the agricultural sector in crisis situations, and these funds are achieved by reducing direct payments, but only among those farmers who receive support of more than EUR 2 000 (exceptions are farmers from Croatia, Romania and Bulgaria who have not yet reached the 100% subsidy ceiling). The correction factor is 1.39%, which will provide a reserve of €446.1 million in the 2016 budget. It is worth noting that if the above-mentioned funds are not used, the money returns to farmers the following year.  We are all well aware of how vulnerable agriculture is and how easy it is to disrupt the functioning of the market, lead to over-production or huge losses, as a result of which farmers' incomes are drastically decreasing. This is influenced not only by weather conditions, climate change, but also by the political situation in Europe and beyond (recent examples of which are, for example, the olive grove epidemic, disturbances in the dairy sector or the effects of the Russian embargo). Therefore, the crisis reserve is an absolute necessity, a mechanism guaranteeing the smooth functioning of European agriculture, which I fully support.

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the report by Maria Noichl on behalf of the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality on the EU strategy for equality between women and men for the period after 2015 (2014/2152(INI)) (A8-0163/2015).

name: Maria NOICHL
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report, which is a very important one. Before I would like to say a few words about the EU's strategy for equality between women and men after 2015, I would like to express my sincere thanks to all those who have helped to launch a good, balanced strategy. This thanks go very well to the shadow rapporteurs and their teams, as well as to the numerous associations and experts. A heartfelt thank you also to the secretariat of the committee – the cooperation was truly exemplary. The strategy has a major objective: to move gender equality in Europe in the right direction. This equality is already enshrined in the first European Treaties, but unfortunately everyday life in Europe is different. That is why we now finally need a strategy that shows a way forward in a targeted and powerful way and, above all, proposes concrete solutions. I see four specific objectives at the heart of this. In Europe, 500 million people live in very different life situations: young and older people in families and as singles, with and without disabilities, with European citizenship and without. An important objective of our strategy must be to take account of this diversity and to keep an eye on everyone, really everyone. A second point: good equality policy can be recognised by the fact that issues must not be considered in isolation and individually, but must always be interdependent. It is therefore an important objective of the strategy to disclose the relationships between the thematic areas and to develop an overall strategy. Growth and employment are important issues, but they must not obscure other issues: issues such as violence, health, media, work, time, finance and so on. In addition, the EU must always stand up for the values of equality in its external relations. A third point: effective equality policy must always be measured against four points – an honest analysis of the situation, the recognition of progress, the identification of problems and then the display of very concrete solutions.
