One of the aims of my report is to make realistic proposals and suggestions by taking an honest look at the reality of life. Fourthly, responsible equality policy does not promise rapid success. Settings changes take time. A very important objective of my report is to recognise subsidiarity and to present what is politically possible in a very differentiated and clear way. Best practice models are particularly important here in order to inspire Member States and to support them on their own path. Ladies and gentlemen, together with the shadow rapporteurs, we have managed to enshrine all these objectives in the report. There are many suggestions, ideas and ideas of European citizens. Europe is a community of values. With the adoption of the strategy for gender equality, we are taking a step in the right direction. And we go it together, with all the women and with all the men in Europe. (Applause)

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank the rapporteur, Ms Noichl, for her report, which represents a key input in setting our future priorities in the area of equality. The Commission’s commitment in this respect is as strong as ever. Equality between women and men is a fundamental value, an objective of the European Union and also a driver for economic growth. It is the Commission’s firm intention to continue to promote equality in all EU activities, internal and external, as required by the Treaty. My staff have started a consultative process with major stakeholders and the broader public, as all their views and experience are very important in terms of shaping our future activity. I would like to thank Parliament, and in particular the Committee on Women’s Rights and Gender Equality, for its contribution to the Forum on the Future of Gender Equality in the European Union, organised in April this year. We are also cooperating closely with the Member States and other important stakeholders such as the social partners and civil society. We are interested in an inclusive process, taking advantage of the expertise of others. Let me highlight the areas where I believe we need, together, to step up our efforts: achieving economic independence in equality; the eradication of gender-based violence; and the defence and promotion of women’s rights and gender equality at global level. These correspond to a large extent to the priorities identified in your report. If we want women to be economically independent, we need to address the existing gender gaps, be they in pay, participation or pensions. As said in your report, we must also not ignore the high number of women living in poverty and social exclusion. Our tools are the monitoring of the situation in the context of the Europe 2020 Strategy and the possibility of proposing Country Specific Recommendations; the implementation and enforcement of the EU legislation; and the exchange of good practices and mutual learning. We should reflect on a new approach to tackling work-life balance. Both women and men should be able to participate fully in the labour market while not giving up on their family life. The challenges are to improve the accessibility of care facilities and the effective provision of family leave and flexible working arrangements, paying particular attention to the participation of men. Also, we still need more women in decision-making positions, be it in companies, in the economy or in politics. Negotiations on our directive, setting a 40% target for the under-represented sex on company boards, are an absolute priority for us, and we need to conclude this proposal. Our approach is merit-based, putting the focus on a fair and transparent selection process, which will bring about significant change. As to violence against women, one in three women in the EU has experienced violence. We have to find policy responses that bring about a real improvement in the lives of women and girls in Europe. This includes looking into the possibility of the EU acceding to the Istanbul Convention. I strongly believe that this Council of Europe convention is a powerful common framework for combating violence against women. When addressing violence against women we need to combine the internal and the external perspective. I will work closely with colleagues Mogherini and Mimica to tackle the phenomenon of female genital mutilation (FGM), including beyond the EU. We will look at all available means of ensuring gender equality: legislation and its effective implementation, funding of projects and campaigns, and gender mainstreaming with specific measures. We also need a monitoring system with clear indicators so as to make ourselves accountable to EU citizens. I count on your support in working together to achieve equality between women and men. It is very important that the European Parliament sends a unified and strong signal on the future of gender-equality policies in the EU.

name: Agnieszka KOZŁOWSKA
text: author of the draft opinion of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I would like to highlight in today's discussion the topic of the importance of gender equality for the competitiveness and growth of the European Union economy. Equality between women and men in the labour market is undoubtedly a matter of social justice, a fundamental civil right, but it is also a prerequisite for sustainable and sustainable economic growth. Making full use of women's qualifications, education and talents brings real profits to businesses and the economy. The presence of women on boards, the presence of women in positions is associated with the company's profits. The presence of women in the labour market has a significant impact on the level of their pensions and is the first reason that can help close the pension gap – the 39% pension gap in Europe is a great shame, this pension gap should be the first starting point and reference for building equality policies, and we know well that to do this we need crèches, kindergartens, care services and the possibility of reconciling work and family life.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Commissioner, honourable Report-making Woman, I would like to thank you for your support. I think it is very important, as you have found, that promoting equal opportunities between women and men is an important common cause. I would like to say to you that this is exactly how the PP group thinks on this issue. It not only supports, but also fights, to ensure that this equal opportunities can be achieved. It is a pleasure for me to be able to find common ground on this subject. It is also natural, however, that we are all different, we come from different cultures, or we may have different values. These differences can be displayed in country-specific recommendations, or in the positions that we display here in Parliament in order to show the values and interests of our constituents, our constituents.  I regret that this has not been fully done in this very important report. I would like to protect this subject from the use of the issue of equal opportunities for women and men as a tool. It's a more important topic than using it as a tool.  It is therefore time to respect member states' competences on this issue, to enforce the principle of subsidiarity and not to interfere in the field of others – I understand each other's territory. It is also important to understand that there are topics– this is exactly the same – where reports cross this line and even cross boundaries. It is not good, or even harmful, to force others to do things that harm this subject. Unrealistic measures, their suggestions, are not required in these reports. It was along these lines that the PP group drafted its own alternative motion for a resolution, showing the strategic and operational issues of the subject. Unfortunately, this is not included in the report, which is why I cannot support it.

name: Maria ARENA
text: On behalf of the Group of S-D. - Mr President, I thank Maria Noichl for the work she has done in this report, which can be described as an ambitious report, a concrete report, but also a report which gives legislative avenues and, above all, establishes conditions and opens up funding opportunities. To my colleague from the EPP Group, since he came up with an alternative proposal, I would like to say that the EPP group is not ambitious. It is not committed, it does not show funding, it does not show a legislative position.  I find it a real pity on the part of this Parliament not to be able to send a clear message even though the strategies of the past tell us that more needs to be done. Even today, there are discriminations in employment and employment rates that are not favourable to women. Discrimination in wages and pensions, as well as ethical discrimination, continues to exist. Women are victims of violence in Europe today. They do not have access to sexual and reproductive health everywhere.  We must ensure that these discriminations are abolished in our system in Europe, but not only in Europe. We also want Europe to be a driving force in external relations so that it can promote this equality in the world.  Europe has the opportunity to do so and it must have the ambition to do so. This Parliament must make that commitment.  As you have said, Commissioner, you need a clear message from this Parliament and Mrs Noichl's report goes in that direction. We hope that all Members of this House will be able to support this report, because we women need ambition.  Once again, thank you to Maria Noichl for the work that has been done.   (The speaker agreed to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation)

name: Raymond FINCH
text: blue-card question. – Would my colleague agree with me that it is an utter disgrace that a debate on something as crucial as this is attended so poorly? It looks like there are no more than 20 or 30 people in the entire Chamber.

name: Maria ARENA
text: "blue card" answer. Mr President, it is true that, in general, when we talk about these subjects, there are few of us, but I hope that there will be many of us to vote for this report. So I will give you an appointment tomorrow, at the time of the vote, so that together we can support it. The fact that we are not here, in the spans, does not mean that we are not aware of the challenges we face in terms of equality of opportunity.

name: Jadwiga WIŚNIEWSKA
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – We are discussing today a controversial and dangerous report, which is intended to be a coherent and effective strategy for equality between women and men. Such an ideal strategy should be a field of cooperation between women and men and be based on access to equal opportunities in a way that respects and appreciates the natural differences between them. However, the report that is being discussed with the actual idea of equality has nothing to do with it. Promotes abortion as one of reproductive rights, interferes with education by implementing a gender perspective at every level of education, calls for the adoption of a directive establishing gender quotas on company supervisory boards, undermines the natural identity of the family, promotes LGBT parenting, and points to the duty to combat stereotypes and traditional perceptions of the roles of women and men, and calls for the involvement of the Commission and the Member States in the in vitro procedure. The provisions of the report interfere with the competences of the Member States and are incompatible with national rules. This report is a set of different solutions: good and bad, but unfortunately the bad ones will open the door to social dismantling and under-balancing the institutions of the family. It is these threats that are at the heart of it. This report must not be accepted, which is why I will support Amendment 1 tomorrow, which respects the division of competences between the Union and the Member States and takes into account the norms of international and EU law in the field of health and family policy. Let us not allow the idea of equality between men and women to be just a field of unnecessary ideological struggle. (The speaker agreed to answer the question asked by raising the blue card (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: blue-card question. – The European Union talks a lot about the principle of subsidiarity: that decisions should be made at the closest possible level to the citizen. It seems to me that we have something here where the decision is being taken further away. Do you agree with me that these matters really should be decided at a national level?

name: Jadwiga WIŚNIEWSKA
text: answer to the question asked by raising the blue card. "We definitely do, and that's what we're saying in this spirit. These issues should be resolved by the Member States and it is the Member States that have the right to policy on this issue, so I believe that the adoption of the report discussed today should absolutely not take place tomorrow. In addition, interfering with education, introducing a gender perspective at every level of education and showing that the source of violence is so-called stereotypical roles, and stereotypical roles are considered the role of a woman as a wife and mother, a man as a father – I say emphasically no to such actions. It is up to the Member States to decide on the education system, on family policy and on family policy.

name: Angelika MLINAR
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take a iendled with the ALDE Group. Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. First of all, I would like to thank my colleague Maria Noichl in the first form for the truly excellent work she has done here. The report we voted for in committee criticises the growing stalemate in gender equality and calls on the Commission to develop a new EU strategy for women's rights and equality between women and men after 2015. I am pleased that I have been able to contribute to a report that sets the political course for equality between women and men for the next five years and which contains concrete proposals for improvement on many important issues. We have managed to develop a holistic package of measures that deal with disadvantages in different areas of life. Violence against women, the difficult role of women in the labour market and the issue of reproductive health are just a few examples of the issues raised by this report. And only by making holistic and comprehensive proposals to the Commission can we manage to improve the situation of women in Europe and make equality between women and men a priority for the EU. Unfortunately, as we have just heard, however, there are Colleagues who oppose this report, hiding behind the protective cloak of subsidiarity. I would like to remind these very members that we will not be voting on a legislative report tomorrow, and more importantly, that we are talking here about measures that will achieve our European values, as the previous speakers and, above all, the Commissioner have already stressed – namely those common and universal values, which are clearly enshrined in Article 2 of the Treaty on European Union. Furthermore, Article 23 of the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights explicitly provides for the adoption of measures to strengthen the under-represented sex. Therefore, I do not think that we can speak of a lack of a legal basis in this case. I hope that, in tomorrow's vote, we will be able to send a strong signal for a new strategy for gender equality, thereby proving that Europe takes its responsibility towards women seriously. We must not lose sight of one thing: the real problem is that we are writing 2015 and that there is not a single country in this whole world where women are equal to men. I very much hope that we will be able to find a clear answer in this House in this regard. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Janusz KORWIN-MIKKE
text: blue-card question. – We accept and understand that women and men have equal skills and talents. Unfortunately, when I am watching TV there is a programme called Extreme Sports, and there are no women. In all extreme sports there are no women. I think you should demand that there be at least 40% of women jumping on motor cycles and so on. Moreover, there is a list of ‘100 best chess players’. We should demand that at least 40% of the best chess players should be women and, of course, if necessary, we should change the rules of chess so that we have at least 40% of women on the list of best chess players. What do you think about this?

name: Angelika MLINAR
text: blue-card answer. – I have to admit that I do not really understand what your question was, but if you are trying to refer to women maybe being less talented at chess than men, then I simply have to say that you are not right.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: On behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr First of all, I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Noichl, and the other colleagues in the Committee on Gender Equality for their work together. For us in the GUE/NGL, gender equality and feminism are absolutely central to the societies in which we want to build and live. It is fundamental to fairer societies, to a future that values equality, that sees that our democracies today are not democratic enough and that sees that our economies must integrate both production and reproduction. It takes quite a lot of changes to make up with hundreds, not to say perhaps thousands, of years of patriarchal dominion. So the dream of a society on an equal footing is a big dream, and women's struggle for justice and equality has been paved with difficulties and resistance – everything from the right to vote, the right to work, the right to inherit, the right to abortion and contraception. I am proud and grateful for the sisters who went before me, before us sitting here tonight. But they will also be our yardstick, and it is surprising how much resistance is actually left.  We who work on these issues do not always share the same feminist strategies, but most of us are actually genuinely interested in building societies that are more equal, where girls and boys, women and men have the same opportunities and rights, and that we are entering the future. It is about the struggle for financial independence, the struggle for a life that is not limited by violence and the threat of violence, a society in which we expand the lives of girls and women, where girls are allowed to grow up in firm belief that the right to their own body and their own sexuality is theirs, not just on paper in a legal clause, but really, for real.  Young women do not want to live in the Europe of old men. They want an assembly here that is taking new steps and it is a long time since the EU actually did anything to create a more equal society. In fact, legislation for a few hundred women in the board of directors is not enough. This report on which we are going to vote tomorrow is not perfect, but it is ambitious, as some colleagues have said. It takes a holistic approach and it has been supported and wet in the Committee on Gender Equality, and civil society has had its say.  This is not about subsidiarity, it is about whether we support women's rights and gender equality or whether we continue to be part of the old conservative resistance. Tomorrow we are voting against the EPP resolution and we are voting in favour of the rapporteur's resolution by the Committee on Gender Equality. (The speaker agreed to answer a question (blue card) in accordance with Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure).

name: Louise BOURS
text: blue-card question. – Feminism – you were just talking about feminism then, and discrimination. I just would like your opinion, please. If a gentleman, a male MEP, had stood up in this Parliament and said that men do not want to live in a Europe of old women, what would the feminists amongst us have said? I am sure there would be uproar – but that is just what you have said, and I personally find that equally offensive. I think discrimination has to work both ways, and as a feminist you cannot stand there and make statements like that without then having the contrary, backing it up. So to my mind, to say that women do not want to live in a Europe full of old men is just the same as a man standing up and saying a man does not want to live in a Europe full of old women.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: blue-card answer. – In an equal society I would not dream of calling anyone anything, but in this society I have been fighting for women’s and girls’ equal rights for long enough, and I have met a lot of resistance. Believe me: that resistance is mainly from older men, and in this Chamber that is even more true. So I am not taking it anymore; I am not having it anymore. I can name something for what it is: we see a lot of male resistance to gender equality in this room, and it has to stop. I want equality in this Chamber, too, by the way – quotas tomorrow!

name: Terry REINTKE
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, gender quality is not just the cherry on the cake of democracy: it is the very fundament of democracy and a founding principle of the European Union. Without full access for women to economic independence, without equal representation of women in our decision-making structures, without women having power over their own bodies, we will not reach full equality. The European Parliament cannot merely claim this; we need to act and to propose legislation to really implement this equality, including basic rights such as sexual and reproductive rights. When we say ‘my body, my choice’ this statement means much more than just deciding in relation to our reproductive organs. It means empowerment for all women, reclaiming the power over their own bodies, reclaiming a power and a right that we hold, but that have been taken away from us in the last hundreds of years – a right that is so simple and so clear that it makes me sad that we still have to fight for it today. To those on the right of the House, I would say this: it is simply untrue constantly to claim that asking for sexual and reproductive rights is promoting abortion. The exact opposite is true. Asking for sexual and reproductive rights means giving women back the power over their own bodies. It means fighting against the fact that, still today, 68 000 women die in unsafe and illegal abortions each year. I tell you here and now that if you want to fight against abortion, do not fight us – do not fight the women asking to have control over their bodies. Fight for the empowerment of women; fight for sex education; fight for free access to contraception; fight for a society where women can make choices; fight for sexual and reproductive rights – because abortions, especially in illegal and unsafe surroundings, are much more frequent in countries with very restrictive laws on abortion, where women do not hold the right over their own body and where they do not have access to contraception. So colleagues, please vote in favour of the initial report as proposed by Ms Noichl, and empower women to have a right over their own bodies. When we talk about women, we need to see the whole picture. Without acknowledging the diversity of our struggles, we will never reach full emancipation. Lesbian women, women of colour, trans women, women with disabilities, poor women, young and old women – all must have their needs and demands reflected in this joint strategy for gender equality post 2015. And yes, we will also need male allies, because this struggle is not only the cherry on the cake: as I said, it is a struggle that will change our entire societies for all of us, making them more just, more inclusive and more resilient. If we want to be successful we cannot ask only for the cherry on the cake, and we cannot ask only for a bigger share of the cake. We need to fight for the whole bakery. Let us build an equal, inclusive and diverse society. Let us not only make this strategy a cornerstone for women’s rights and emancipation: let us go further, creating a comprehensive post-2015 strategy that will mainstream our demands in all fields of European Union politics.

name: Daniela AIUTO
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the aim of this report is to establish new strategies for equality between men and women by the European Union after 2015 and, given its corposity, it is clear how much more work needs to be done in the various fields. Indeed, while we must support and praise the attention that is being paid to issues such as discrimination in the workplace, pay diversity or the fight against violence against women, with yet another call for ratification of the Istanbul Convention for the various Member States that have not yet done so, there are, on the other hand– some aspects in this report that are perplexing. We are witnessing yet another attempt to include issues which are supposed to be the responsibility of the European Union and which are and should remain the responsibility of the Member States.  In fact, if you read the title of this report, you expect a certain type of content, namely measures to promote equality between men and women – and instead we are faced with the imposition of issues that have nothing or little to do with this subject. I would like the reports of the Committee on Women's Rights not to be used periodically to become the receptacle from time to time where interference by one or more lobbies, which should not interfere with issues of equality between men and women, can be brought together. I would also have liked to see, in addition to the call for a gender-conscious pedagogical training campaign for teachers, so that they can convey the values of gender equality, there should also be an explicit reference to education and feelings towards young people. Why is that? Because a boy who grows up with an awareness of respect for the woman, understanding what it really means to love her, will become a man unable to abuse a future companion with psychological and physical violence. On the other hand, if we read the statistics, in the vast majority of cases feminicides take place at the hands of their partner.  From now on, I call for the individual aspects included in the reports not to obscure the many positive elements on which we must focus our attention and on which we must work. All this so as not to detract from the importance of the strategies promoted to try to solve the varied problems related to equality issues.

name: Vicky MAEIJER
text: – I have no less than 40 pages of text on gender equality here: 40 pages criticising the Member States on issues such as the distribution of household tasks, maternity leave, pensions, wages, childcare, the introduction of women's quotas for supervisory boards and even for parliaments. What the hell is this Parliament interfering in? This discussion belongs in the national parliaments.  And 40 pages of text and not a single word in it about Islam, that ideology with medieval views of the position of man and woman. For according to Islam, a man's testimony is worth as much as that of two women, and a man may marry more than one woman and one woman only one man, and the woman in inheritance does not get the same as a man in her position. This is an ideology that is gaining a foothold in the EU, and a Gender Equality Commission, which forgets to mention this in a report on gender equality, is really not worth a cut.  (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: Blue card question. Thank you, Mr President. Have I not understood what you are accusing the European Union of? It says that forty pages highlight problems which obviously affect the individual countries of the European Union and the non-respect of the general rules that the European Union, not in violation of the principle of subsidiarity, but through the principle of coordination, proposes. And I have not really understood what you are criticising the European Union for! Criticise those States that do not respect the rules of equality between men and women which, I believe, are one of the founding aspects of European values.

name: Vicky MAEIJER
text: "blue card" answer. I have been a member of this parliament for almost a year now.  All these reports on gender equality that have passed so far, both this report and reports on genital mutilation or forced marriage: firstly, these are all areas where the debate should be held in the national parliaments and not here. I'm critical of that. This is a pure violation of the principle of subsidiarity. My second point: if you are so committed to equality between men and women, why are the Commission and Parliament failing in all these reports to name the role of women and the position of women in Islam? Then why do you leave that behind?

name: Elissavet VOZEMBERG-VRIONIDI
text: PPE). Mr President, the mere fact that we see that only women and men have registered and requested speaking time with a blue card shows that the objective has not been achieved. The report is indeed of strategic importance, I fully agree with our Commissioner, who said that equality is an objective, a goal and a lever for growth, but we should avoid reports in which opinions are distorted that null and void the objective.  The target has not been achieved. But in order to achieve how we, the European Parliament, the European Council, the Commission, the European Union, as an institutional player, could make a decisive contribution, so that after years we do not talk about this issue. Only if the mentality changes and in order to change the mentality, ladies and gentlemen, does the nursery called the family, the nursery called school, with education and systematic guidance be needed to educate children, so that future generations realise that between men and women there is no difference in the opportunities that individuals are entitled to, especially in key areas. , such as education, senior posts, the glass ceiling - I am referring to individual issues in the time available to me - where not only have steps not been taken, but we can say that steps have been taken backwards.  This is not the fault, ladies and gentlemen, of the principle of subsidiarity, which I have heard said from somewhere, because national law has its own autonomy. But we have an institutional role and we must, we must, intervene where we give European directions. For me, ladies and gentlemen, the objective and purpose and the lever for development lies in changing attitudes, but provided that we work this subject and that we really demonstrate in practice that we mean it and we are not just drawing up reports of literary, theoretical content.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: Mr President, I cannot but praise Mary's report here. We all know that the economic crisis and austerity measures have not treated men and women equally. Women left at a disadvantage and this disadvantage increased during the crisis. We have seen a regression in the progress made towards gender equality and we must be able to give a sensitive and firm response to gender issues in an attempt to reverse this trend. The adoption of this report will be a very important step in this direction. I would remind you that in most countries affected by the economic crisis, we are seeing an increasing feminisation of poverty. The main beneficiaries of food banks are women and with at least one child. In Europe, there are on average seven times more single-parent families headed by women than men. Many women's reception centres who are victims of violence have been forced to close due to budget cuts. Poor or at-risk women are more likely to do poor, precarious and unusual work, and also face the risk of exploitation and trafficking in human beings. Freezing pensions in the context of austerity puts older women at greater risk of poverty. And finally, women depend more than men in terms of tax benefits.  These and many other warnings come to us from everywhere and we insist on ignoring them. Many European governments have actually implemented austerity measures that aggravate the negative effect of the economic crisis on women. It is therefore essential to be in mind that constraints on women's economic autonomy constitute obstacles to the protection of basic rights and human dignity itself. So tomorrow we must approve this report. There is always an alternative that does not mean attacking human rights. We are the ones who make these alternatives and I am very sorry that on that side we do not want to make this change.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the After Estrella and Tarabella comes the Noichl report. I would like to quote paragraph 60, as it says literally: the European Parliament calls on the European Commission to implement sex education programmes in schools. Could it be that some people here had a bit of sex education and a little bit of basic course in terms of the competence of the European Union? Schools are the exclusive responsibility of the Member States and no one else, especially the EU Commission! And then, of course, it's about sex education. Should this be done according to the standards of sex education in Europe, by the World Health Organisation, the Regional Office for Europe, framework for educational institutions? I quote the teaching content of page 42: Positive attitudes develop towards socially constructed gender called gender and early childhood masturbation. This is recommended for the age group 0-4 years, 0-4! Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. It's nice that you're there. I would ask you for one thing: strengthen the rights of parents, where you are responsible for them. Strengthen and support the family when you are responsible for it. But leave the hands of the children in God's name! And then there is paragraph 31 of the Noichl report: the EU Parliament recommends that family law should also be applied to single parents because of the changing concept of family. Again, family policy is a national competence! But allow a question: should that mean family law for single parents, i.e. marriage without a partner, marriage for all, marriage alone? It's getting crazier! It is good that opposition to this is also growing, here in Parliament and on the streets. Unfortunately, I have to say that the Noichl report was, at best, a mere waste of tax.

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: – Mr President; Commissioner; thank you very much, Mrs Noichl, for your deep, ambitious and consensus work.  Why are we talking about strategy for equality between men and women? Because it's a goal, because it's a goal, because we haven't made it.  The ongoing evaluations of the current strategy show that we have achieved some of the objectives, but progress has been slow and uneven, and we still have many challenges to overcome. Unfortunately, in the European Union we have several examples of Member States that are regressing on equality.  The beneficial effects of gender equality on society as a whole and in all areas – economic, social and political – are more than proven, and above all because it is the greatest guarantee of an egalitarian society that rests on fundamental rights that give meaning to our value system.  The European Union recognises in the Treaties equality between women and men as a fundamental courage and objective. That is why this report is of crucial importance: it sets out the strategy for the Union's work programme for the next five years.  The European Parliament needs to send a strong and determined political message on progress on gender equality, and also to international actors who, like the United Nations, are waiting for us to send a clear and firm signal to support their work on gender equality, a key part of the 2015-2030 development goals. Mrs Jourová, the Commission's 2015-2020 equality strategy will be the first major work of the first police station which specifically includes gender equality in its portfolio. Let us take note of the mistakes made in the 2010-2015 Strategy so as not to repeat them: their implementation has been hampered by a lack of resources and limited capacities, but the necessary resources must be allocated for the investment to bear fruit and to link explicit actions, objectives, deadlines and responsibilities.  From Parliament's Committee on Women's Rights, we have taken note of these problems and made a balanced proposal, which seeks to respond to all areas where inequality exists. I would like to highlight the improvement of rights at European level in the LGBTI collective, the improvement of the presence of women in business and, above all, I urge again to sign the Istanbul Convention by the Union through a Commission proposal which the Council is awaiting.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: GUE/NGL). Mr President, today we are discussing the adoption of a new strategy for equality between men and women, at a time when the complete failure of the previous one for the years 2010 to 2015 is reflected in the figures. 60% of the population who are out of work are women, but those with jobs are paid on average 16% less than men for equal value work. These figures are growing in crisis countries such as Greece, where the recession, as a result of memorial policies, has sent one in three women into unemployment.  The great words of the report will not help either the unemployed mother, the woman who does not become pregnant for fear of losing her job, nor the woman who becomes a receiver of violence. Austerity policies not only do not promote equality between men and women, but instead exacerbate inequality and it is our duty to reverse them.

name: Ernest MARAGALL
text: – Mr President, this is an ambitious, well-crafted, well-finished resolution. And I think, anyway, I'm surprised that others find it excessive and even dangerous. At any rate, I find it prudent and in some respects even self-limiting. We're certainly going to give him determined support. Here too, also in the field of gender equality, we need Europe more and better, not to replace member states, but to add, to complement, to help countries and regions complete their own path with this common objective of gender equality.  Let me talk about three very specific issues: education, economic crisis and market and social roles. In education—not said so far—the role of early childhood education must be emphasized. It is more than proven: early incorporation into education has great effects in the field of gender equality and in the field of long-term personal independence. The positive correlation between the two issues is fully proven. And, second educational topic, the initial training of teachers and educators is essential if we are to achieve success in this field.  Second, economic crisis and new migrations. In recent years Europe has lost, it has gone backwards in this field. The economic crisis has produced havoc, very clear damage to gender equality. It seems to me that we have been victims of the supposed virtues of the free market and we have then been punished for austerity policies, for budget cuts. In addition, new internal migrations add the complexity derived from cultural and religious diversity, very often in contrast to and contradiction with the European references so far, which seemed consolidated. That is why specific policies must be adopted. The European Union cannot be limited to a monitoring or measurement role. It needs to take a proactive attitude of promotion, support and accompaniment to each country, including the definition of objectives, the programming of appropriate policies and resources and the shared monitoring of their compliance. And finally: market and social roles. We have lived on the absolute imposition of the free market, the incitement to unlimited consumption, the maximum exploitation of male and female roles, precisely. These are features associated with the economic model of financial deregulation and globalization of exchanges that, for thirty years, he has wanted to define us. We will not move forward on gender equality without a clear rectification of that course. It makes no sense that all public policies, all educational efforts are negatively compensated by social and economic behavior that, day after day, confirms and expands stereotypes, roles and functions awarded to each gender. And you have to change them both: the feminine one, no doubt; but also the masculine one, which reproduces habits of exercise of power or domination, and which entails female subordination and dependence.

name: Louise BOURS
text: – Mr President, the resolution urges the adoption of a directive for the balanced representation of men and women on boards. This is a piece of EU legislation that allows for sanctions such as the dissolution of a company just because it has not succeeded in reaching the arbitrary target imposed by the European Union. You do not fight discrimination with discrimination. Bringing in quotas is demeaning for women – the women who have worked hard and made it to the top of their professions. It should not matter what gender you are or what your ethnic background or religion is: if you are the best-qualified person for that job, you should get it. But with the instigation of these policies, people could look around the boardroom and question whether a colleague is the best person for the job, or if they simply obtained their position because their gender ticked the right boxes on the EU checklist. Paragraph 56 calls for the Commission to create best-practice models for sex and relationship education for young people. Paragraph 60 urges the Commission to implement sex education programmes in schools and ensure counselling and access to contraception. It is outrageous, absolutely outrageous, that the EU seeks to interfere with the Member States’ education systems, especially with regard to sex education. And, to top things off, in the explanatory statement you even say who should be doing the housework. If I can quote directly from it: ‘men will have to devote more time to the housework’. What kind of organisation interferes to this extent in the private lives of people, their marriages and their partnerships? It is up to adults in the privacy of their own homes to decide who does what. It is not the place of any government, and it certainly is not the place of EU bureaucrats to decide who does and who does not do the dishes. In 1975 the UK voted to join a Europe of free trade and friendship, not a European Union of political control and social engineering. This is yet another reason to vote ‘no’ in the upcoming UK referendum. Let us regain our freedom and independence from these meddling EU bureaucrats.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: Mr President, there is unanimous support for women's delicate mission of ensuring the fragile balance between their family and working lives. It is also vital to commit to the rights of the most vulnerable human beings, often in situations of dependency, such as children, the elderly or the disabled. This fight should be the fight of all, although it is absolutely not within the competence of this assembly. However, when I read your proposals, I am struck by the terrible contradictions that mark this report, particularly between its objectives and the means it advocates to achieve it. Explain to us: how is it possible to defend women by advocating gender theory and gender indifferentiation? How is it possible to defend the lives of the most vulnerable beings by defending abortion as an inalienable right? How is it possible to defend the balance of the family by destroying its very conception and its natural definition? You take the goodwill of all hostage through scabrous intellectual theories and, above all, disconnected from reality. This report does no one any favours, especially women, and it will further fuel voter disgust if the European Union does not free itself from certain deadly ideologies.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Mr President, I wanted to say and react in this way to my colleague Björg's speech that, although I am not an old man, I will vote against the MarieNoichl report because a good compromise has not been found in the FEMM committee. Unfortunately, the report does not focus on what is really important and what we can help. After all, we know that women's salaries have not been increased, that there is indeed still a 16% difference in the European Union, that there is still a pension gap, 39% between women and men, that although there is a large proportion of women in universities, this does not correspond to the number in which women are represented in business leaders, political positions or universities. I think that this report simply does not respond to what is essential. Why is this the case? Why are women less paid, why do they have more trouble asserting themselves? This is natural, because women simply have one more crucial role in which they are not substitutable, and that is their role as a mother. This, of course, makes them handicapped in some way when pursuing their professional careers. The result of insufficient support measures is that most European nations are dying out. Europe has no problem with women not having access to abortion and reproductive care, abortion is a lot in Europe, but women are not sufficiently valued and supported in their reconciliation of maternal and parental function. That is why the European People's Party is coming up with its opinion, which highlights what really needs to be done, i.e. to support women in flexible working hours through public policies, incentives for businesses, the need to ensure a reduction in the pay gap and women's pensions.  I believe that the European Parliament will send a strong signal on this matter.

name: Anna HEDH
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr I have given birth to three children and am not handicapped to sit in the European Parliament. The general pay gap in the EU is currently 16.4% – women earn 16.4% less than men despite having the same job and doing the same tasks. This injustice is due to a number of factors.  It comes from the fact that men have almost always been housed in decision-making positions and thus had control over wage setting. It comes from the fact that we women have long been seen as merely a means of reproduction, which means that the female worker is far more unreliable than her male colleague because she is expected to have children. The different treatment of men and women is not just a problem at the moment – it also poses enormous problems for the future, such as the 39% pension gap in the EU, which puts women in an unsustainable situation throughout their lives.  Women make up more than half of Europe's population, but only 18.6% of eu board members are women and only 5% of eu-executive directors are women.  It is therefore time that, as a first step, we seriously reviewed what measures are needed to ensure that women have the same opportunities as men to lead companies and companies. At the same time, we must also dare to break the standard that values men more when it comes to wage setting.  And if it is not obvious to you now how important this is, only equal participation in the labour market would lead to an increase in GDP per capita of 12.4% by 2030.  What I have now briefly talked about are only a few examples of the injustices that affect women on a daily basis. Injustices that must be brought to an end, for which Mrs Noichl's report is a good tool. If we do not vote in favour of her and the FEMM committee's report, women's economic independence and emancipation will once again be put on hold, as so many times before.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: – I, too, dream and desire a Europe without discrimination. For example, I long for quality and inclusive education to become a reality for all – girls and boys, poor children, children with disabilities, not only in Slovakia, but also in other countries of the European Union. I long for us not to have to deal with access to education in the 21st century and to be able to concentrate our resources and energy, for example, calmly on supporting girls' education in technical directions. However, the reality today is different and very different across Member States. I therefore consider it wrong to overwhelm states with new and new legislation, to deploy quotas and to enter into policies which, by their very nature, are the responsibility of the Member States for the functioning of the European Union. I believe that if we really want to help girls and women in their education, application and overall status, we can achieve better results through patient and ant work at Member State level.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: – Mr President; Thank you, Commissioner; effective equality between men and women is strategic for Europe; it is a matter of justice and fundamental rights, especially the fight against gender-based violence, a silent terrorism that threatens millions of women. In addition, the success of our 2020 model depends on the incorporation of women's talent and capacity into the labour market, innovation and decision-making processes in the public and private spheres. And this sum of human capital is essential because it is intelligent, sustainable and inclusive, in fact it is today our great competitive advantage over competitors still anchored in almost medieval gender roles.  That is why we need to take this issue seriously, incorporate it as a horizontal vector in all Union policies, establish systematic statistics, indicators and assessments, publish the results of these measurements and correct what is necessary until effective equality is achieved. A situation that requires an active involvement of men: it is sufficient for them to wonder what is taking away their inequality.  Unfortunately, bad examples such as the composition of the current European Commission, the Council's attitude towards the Maternity Leave Directive or participation in councils or scandals experienced here with discussions on sexual and reproductive health are daunting signs. They reflect the distance between what we say, what we really think, and what we therefore do.  Let us therefore move from words to deeds, and supporting this report is the first step.

name: Josu JUARISTI ABAUNZ
text: – Mr President, in order to ensure the participation and empowerment of women in politics and society, it is strategic to recognise their dialogue, to democratise governance and to promote their participation in the design of public policies. But, in addition to setting objectives, we must provide ourselves with funding, strengthening specific items for equality policies and ensuring that the gender perspective is actually integrated into the Union's policies and therefore into its budget. And that's just paper today. It must be concreted and reinforced to be cross-cutting and effective. The same applies to education, strategic for social transformation, especially or even more so in this area. The European Union fails to address structural inequality and the many forms of violence faced by women. And it is not a question of whether it is the competence of the Union or the States. They are women's competences and rights, and in some Member States they are losing them.

name: Jordi Vicent SEBASTIA TALAVERA
text: – Mr President; dear colleagues; Commissioner, thank you very much; firstly, we must remember that the five priority areas of the European Strategy for Equality 2010-2015 remain in force. Sadly in force, because we have not managed to solve any: no economic independence for women; nor equal pay; nor equality in decision-making places; nor are we done with sexist violence; nor have we applied the gender perspective in our foreign policy.  The post-2015 strategy is therefore an urgency and a vital need for this craving for equality to come, and equality is the only way to truly ensure compliance with human rights in the European Union.  We cannot therefore adopt a weak strategy that does not have specific and measurable measures. In this regard, with the nuances of our amendments, this report is welcome and I would like to thank the rapporteur for her work.  We must send the European Commission a very clear message. Equality policy is not a secondary issue, it is not an element that we must face because feminist groups are very persistent: it is a vital element.  I have traveled all over the world reporting on the situation of women in Africa, in India: women subjected to forced marriages, mutilation, systematic violence. And I am saddened that in Europe, an oasis amid the terrible situation of women, there are still voices who do not want a strategy that is strongly saddened by equality and which are shocked when we talk about demanding the gender perspective in all political areas. Because here we also have problems, terrible problems, some colleague has indicated this before: one in three European women has experienced sexist violence. We call on the European Commission to be strong, to require member countries that have not yet done so to sign the Istanbul Convention. We ask you to openly push for a European directive against gender-based violence and to clearly point out the legislation of those countries that hide, with formulas such as crime of passion, the brutality of sexist violence.  I am surprised by the statements of a certain part of this House on the imposition of Europe with these strategies in matters such as education or sexual and reproductive rights, or quotas on the board of directors: of course Europe has to have an opinion and demand action in these matters! It is that equality between all citizens of the European Union is a fundamental objective. Have we forgotten about this? It's in all the Treaties! The parties that are represented here mostly agree with these Treaties: in the countries where they govern, they support them. Why do they say when they come here that Europe is getting into national or state issues?  And the only way to ensure this equality is to intervene in education as well. Sexist stereotypes are maintained and even reinforced in European youth.  The future is not very promising. If Europe makes any sense, it is to join forces to improve the lives of citizens, beyond the states, where states do not arrive. And in the fight for equality, the reports are clear: they don't come. And so must the European Commission be blunt, and so must we. The fight for equality is the struggle for Europe.

name: Sylvie GODDYN
text: Mr President, once again, we are presented with a very militant report on gender equality. So militant that it hijacks the fight against violence and discrimination against women to promote immigration and LGBT communitarianism. However, there are positive things in this report, such as the fight against harassment, forced marriages, genital mutilation, wage inequality or the dismissal of pregnant women. However, this report also contains many elements that do not defend women and do not fall within the competence of the European Union. In particular, it is unacceptable that Member States should be asked to recognise medically assisted reproduction as a right to the child, effectively disregarding the rights of the child. This right to the LDC will flow mechanically on the GPA, that is, the commodification of women's bodies, in the name of equality between same-sex couples. Facilitating illegal immigration does no harm to women. Introducing gender theory into schools does no harm to women. Depriving thousands of unborn children from their fathers does no harm to women.  In short, voting for this report would not do women any favours either.

name: Angelika NIEBLER
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. Equality between men and women is a very important issue. And it has been mentioned that there is still a great deal to be done. Consider the pay gap – 16% across the European Union between men's and women's salaries – the poverty of women in old age, the difficult issue of violence against women. So there is a lot to do. I would have liked to have supported Mrs Noichl's report, and this is because it is her first report. Unfortunately, however, I cannot do that because much of it is contained in the report, which does not reflect my view. That is why I would now like to make a strong campaign for our group's alternative resolution. The report addresses issues that clearly fall within the competence of the European Member States: family planning and abortion are not a European issue, but a matter for the Member States, just as health and education issues are not a European issue, but a matter for the Member States. Not every issue in Europe is also an issue for Europe. That is why I cannot support the report, but I hope that the alternative resolution will also provide us with a majority tomorrow. The European Union has many tasks and a great deal of work in this area too. For example, in the fight against trafficking in women and in the fight against forced prostitution. Ladies and gentlemen, it is a disgrace what is happening in our Member States in this sector before our very eyes. We are all called upon to do this, and the European Commission is called upon to fight and take action on a massive scale of organised trade, organised crime in the interests of our women – but please let the Member States do their homework, for which the Member States are better suited and also better responsible! (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: Question put in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure. – Dear lady, you have shown here, and many speakers have said of subsidiarity, and that member countries should solve their problems. Today we are discussing a real situation: these problems are not solved. Then why do you not agree that we need such a report - and I congratulate it - and that we need a European Union programme whereby we can reach the target we want, which is equal opportunities for women in all areas. Why do you not agree if the situation we are having today is unsatisfactory by letting each country do what it wants? I congratulate all the men who supported the report... (The President interrupted the speaker.)

name: Angelika NIEBLER
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. I can be brief: I stand by my view that there are issues that fall exclusively within the national competence of the Member States. And even if it is a problem that we have identified here in the European Parliament as such, that does not change the question of competence. The Member States must do what problems have to be solved in the Member States. We cannot replace and undermine our national parliaments here at European level, but that is a matter for the Member States, and that is what the individual countries must take care of. That is why I think it is right to point this out again in our alternative resolution, in which we have also raised many individual issues.

name: Mary HONEYBALL
text: – Mr President, I would also like to thank Mrs Noichl for her comprehensive and very valuable report. Much earlier in the debate, Mrs Arena said that we need to send a clear message to ourselves, to the European Union, the Commission and the citizens about gender equality. I think there is one particular issue, which has already been mentioned, which is very important: that is the whole matter of trafficking in human beings, which is one of the most lucrative criminal activities in the world today. Of course, the vast majority of victims of trafficking are women. Eighty percent of victims of trafficking in the EU are women, and most of them, as we know, are trafficked for the purposes of sexual exploitation. We really must do everything that we can to end what is, in effect, modern slavery. We all know there is a directive on human trafficking, but the problem with this has been its implementation. In her report, Maria Noichl calls on Member States to fully implement the Anti-Trafficking Directive. We must do everything that we can in our own Member States to make sure that this is happening, because this is one of the areas where the EU has huge competence. It is the only organisation that can deal with it, because human trafficking is something which has to be done across borders, across countries and across nationalities. We know that our citizens want this, and I know it as a representative of London, which is one of the destinations for trafficked women. Therefore I think we have a particular responsibility, not only in terms of gender equality in itself but particularly in human trafficking. I would say that human trafficking is important for gender equality because the women involved are poor and vulnerable. Therefore I ask all of you to support the report and vote for it tomorrow.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Mr President, Mrs Noichl, ladies and gentlemen to the left of me, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has said. SUBSIDIARITY. Subsidiarity. I have spelled out the word to you, because it seems to me that the Noichl report is further proof that subsidiarity is an annoying term for many when it comes to the enforcement of interests that are sometimes lifeless. Instead of focusing on what is really important in the debate on the gender strategy, on what Europe can do for equal opportunities for women and men, parents and childless people, you are digressing and getting lost in the abstruseness of European competences. I wonder: who is the gender whisperer? Many of the demands of your report certainly do not come from the ladies of her Bavarian SPD, Mrs Noichl: human rights to abortion, sex education in primary school. I repeat: go to your constituents – I'm just saying, "Good luck and God forbid." Together, the PPE-DE and The ECR have opposed an alternative resolution to your collection of reports in Amendment No 1. I would like to reiterate that you support this alternative resolution tomorrow.

name: Gesine MEISSNER
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which Yesterday I read about an editor-in-chief in Saudi Arabia who has many people among her, many workers, but not allowed to drive and has to ask her husband if she wants to go on a business trip. Fortunately, we no longer have such conditions in Europe. But that's why we're not all right. As long as it is not self-evident in the European Union that men and women have equal access to all areas – and I stress that men and women – we have not yet achieved equality and we must write gender reports. It is true that this access is not yet there. We know that men and women are different. In private life, this complements each other quite well and we also deal with each other naturally. In business and politics, however, this is by no means the case. Precisely because men and women are different and have such different qualities, we should also share them. We have seen that an economy can work better if you have mixed teams. Why don't we do that? Why do we still have too few women in politics? As long as that is the case, we really need to see that we can be more successful and do more. A pay gap – that is, unequal pay for equal work – is improbably unfair, and there must be no such thing at all. We must definitely combat this. Fathers and mothers want to reconcile work and family life. In some cases, it is even more difficult for fathers who want to work part-time to be able to do so. We do not want discrimination at all, neither against women nor against men. And, of course, violence against women is very bad. This is something where we also need to take international action, especially in the case of female genital mutilation and violence against women in war – that is not possible at all. That is why the report contains many good things, please agree with it tomorrow!

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: – Mr President, the proposals contained in this report are positive, but they will only be really useful if we combat the structural causes of inequality. Equality is not a straight-line path and the austerity policies of recent years, cuts in social rights and public services are pushing back many of the progress we had made. In addition to sending more and more women into poverty, precariousness effectively means that many women are again invisibly taking over tasks that must be recognized as social rights and services for all. We must also talk about motherhood and fatherhood, a debate very present in this House because, if we do not establish equal paternity and maternity leave, paid one hundred per cent and non-transferable, extending maternity leave only means deepening the role of women as a caregiver removed from the labour market and with more difficulty in entering it. It is a question of justice, but also of economic and social sustainability, that care, in all its senses and variants, be guaranteed and recognized socially and economically.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: – Mr President-in-Office, thank you for the floor, honourable colleagues.  I certainly support and congratulate the rapporteur on the European Union strategy for equality between women and men after 2015. It is a report that is ambitious, which actually draws attention to things that have been going on for many years, and I think it is a good thing that we are also talking about this subject today, because, in fact, gender equality is one of the basic values in the European Union, which has already been recognised in the Treaties and in the Charter of Fundamental Rights. Although the European Union is working on strengthening gender equality, unfortunately at times it seems that this is a process that is far from over, and even more so that this process has even slowed down slightly in recent years, perhaps also because the previous Commission's strategy was somewhat too weak. Therefore, the new strategy will have to give new impetus and lead to concrete measures to strengthen women's rights and promote gender equality.  I do not think that, of course, in these times, we can remain tied to unhelpful and also environmentally unsustainable economic models based on the outdated division of work on the basis of sex. Of course, the economic crisis also contributed, when, as my colleague before me said, it forced many women into these pre-erumatic relationships and, in fact, deepened poverty in some areas.  Therefore, of course, it is also the task of the European Union to come up with appropriate economic and financial incentives to reduce gender inequalities, in addition to reports and strategies, because this is one of the key issues if we are to move these differences forward. Of course, we can talk at the declaratory level about equality, but if, as in the employment of young people, we do the same in the area of gender equality, that is to say, economic incentives, we will, of course, talk about the same problem next year. So I think there needs to be a more decisive step here, and also what my colleagues say, that this is, of course, a matter of subsidity, that this is, of course, also a matter for families, that this is an internal issue, not true. Of course, this is an issue that needs to be brought to the attention, and in fact, most violence against women takes place right within the closed circle, within the families, and it is, of course, for us to draw attention to these things. And subsidiarity is, of course, also a subject on which there will certainly be a debate in the future, but I think that the European Union's task here is very clear, and that is why I support this report. Thanks. (The speaker agreed to accept the question raised by raising the blue card (Rule 162(8)).

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: question posed by raising the blue card. – I would like to ask you because I listened carefully to your presentation do you agree with me that equality, freedom, health were created before subsidiarity? Do you think that equality, freedom, health are what are greater value than subsidiarity, although I am one of those who are very committed to subsidiarity? Do you agree with me?

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: The answer to the question raised by raising the blue card. – Colleague, surely, these are the values you are talking about, which have arisen much before and are also woven into tissue, in fact civilisations. Unfortunately, by doing so, people themselves have intervened in these values in an intolerable way, in a way that we have actually begun to increase differences in different areas and actually undermine those values.  It therefore seems to me right to use subsidiarity, which is, of course, a concept, also in the treaty, logically, carefully, and to use it when it can only encourage it to safeguard those values. Thanks.

name: Diane DODDS
text: – Mr President, this report focuses on many important issues. It focuses on tackling domestic violence, providing access to essential skills and the need to support a work-life balance for young mothers. I fully support efforts to make 2016 the European Year for Combating Violence against Women, and I regret that in recent correspondence with the Commission it has seemed to lack urgency in making this a reality. I would recommend to the House Lord Morrow’s human trafficking bill in Northern Ireland as a good example of national legislation which tackles this evil that is primarily directed against women in our society. However, much of the report we are discussing is a matter of subsidiarity, and it is wrong for this Parliament and European bureaucrats to seek to intrude into national life in this way. As a Member of this Parliament from the United Kingdom, I am looking forward to the debate in our forthcoming referendum, and I have no doubt that this kind of interference will be high on the list of people’s concerns.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I regret to see that the annual reports that the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality draws up precisely to lay the foundations for equality strategies are being used by certain political groups within this Parliament to impose their ideologies. Not many months ago, this Parliament voted for and supported Mr Tarabella's report, a much more balanced report, a more concrete report, where teamwork has been done. In this case, However, I would like to take this opportunity to return to the news, to congratulate the shadow rapporteur, Mrs Gáll-Pelcz, on the efforts she has also made to produce an alternative motion for a resolution, which I call on her to support and vote on tomorrow. It seems surprising, just as many colleagues on the left of this Parliament forget the limitations that the Treaties impose, to have a whole chapter of this text that talks about health is truly paradoxical. For us members of the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality, the development of effective and coherent strategies to eliminate all forms of discrimination against women is a key moment: it is a driving force to be used to direct the European Commission to find concrete solutions to real problems.  Greater cooperation would certainly have benefited women who still have to work three months longer in 2015 than a man to earn the same salary, women who are victims of violence, would have benefited those women who are still forced to work twice as hard to occupy prominent positions in companies.  Here, Mr President, I will conclude, the British political philosopher John Stuart Mill said that there is no better proof of the progress of a civilization than the progress of cooperation; I regret that, in this Commission and in this Parliament, it is not possible to have cooperation.

name: Jutta STEINRUCK
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the First of all, I would like to thank my colleague Maria Noichl for her really very good report. When I listen to some discussion, I feel at the image of women in the Middle Ages. I have the impression that subsidiarity is only being advanced here. For far too long we have been hearing fine words and promises about ending discrimination against women, particularly in the labour market. But too little has happened. The alternative proposal for what the Conservative Members are planning to do also seems to me to be purely cosmetic. In reality, it still decides whether you are a man or a woman, whether you have a good job, whether you are in a managerial position, whether you have a precarious job and what you earn. Women are neither stupid nor less educated than men, and if you include family work, women work much more. In the past, it was the EU level that has repeatedly promoted positive initiatives for equality between women in the Member States. But that commitment has diminished significantly. Especially now in the economic crisis, it is women who are losing their jobs, who have lower-paid jobs, who are involuntarily working part-time. Europe must tackle these problems actively, as it does in other policy areas, such as the fight against youth unemployment. Measures to reduce the so-called gender pay gap have fallen victim to the crisis – or even to competitiveness? Women are above average affected by old-age poverty, they have lower earnings, they have poorer career opportunities. The incompatibility of work and childcare or care also has something to do with the fact that women are really worse off in the labour market. What we need are binding targets within the EU 2020 strategy, especially in the labour market. Equality is not paternalism, equality is a fundamental right. That is what Europe has to do!

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Firstly, I would like to thank the rapporteur for this very comprehensive, ambitious and very concrete report. My compatriot, Mrs Marie Arena, also referred to it. It is a very ambitious, concrete report. But let us be honest, it is actually shameful that we have to have this debate on gender equality here in 2015, that this equality has still not been achieved.  For us liberals, that's actually an obvious thing: it's not your origins, it's your future that counts. But that is apparently not the case for all parties here in this hemisphere when I hear this debate. When I hear that ECR calls for a vote against this report, when I hear that EPP is coming up with an alternative text, where there is no mention of sexual and reproductive health and rights, where people do not dare to talk about access to contraception or access to abortion.  Colleagues, it's in 2015. Wake up! If we don't fight, who's going to fight? I hear a lot of fallacies here, such as where it should be decided. I want to close with a quote from a woman I've always loved, Marilyn Monroe. Women here in the hemisphere, listen to what she said: "Women who want to be equal to men, lack ambition".

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: – Mr President, it is important, yes, a strategy, but a strategy for equality between men and women that goes from role to practice and this unfortunately has not happened. This report has many truths and we will support it. But the reality is that the issues of equality, and in particular the realism of women's rights, cannot be put into a dome, as if they had nothing to do with, in particular, the great political choices and the great economic policy options. And it is important that the large political groups here remember when they have consensus on great macroeconomic options, remember when the European Union, for example, supports cuts in public services, which are the women who suffer the most. When the European Union supports cuts in pensions and widow's pensions, it is also women who suffer the most; when it supports wage cuts, it is women who lower their already low wages. It is women who become less independent and more vulnerable to violence. When they support cuts in social rights, it is women who see limited maternity rights. When they support health cuts, it is women who no longer have access to sexual and reproductive health. And thus, it is possible to square the circle.  Just a small note to say that, although we agree with the whole of this report, we do not agree with the expression 'forced prostitution', because we consider that, in a humanist society, the exploitation of the body and feelings is always forced and, therefore, we want to make this position explicit.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I will strongly and generally oppose the Noichl report, which is just another step in the vast process of destruction of the traditional family, despite a façade, I concede to you, which would be extremely consensual. As my two colleagues from the National Front have pointed out, equality between men and women is only a pretext for this report, which is a catch-all and gives pride of place to the ideology of gender and its different avatars. If not, what would this paragraph do about - quote - "discrimination against transgender people"? What would- and I quote again - do about the "fight against harassment and prejudice against LGBTI people in schools"? There is a totalitarian desire in this report to condition children from an early age, by making them integrate this dehumanized and materialistic conception of the person by reducing it to his sexuality. We are therefore fighting this ideological dogmatism which is not only harmful and dangerous to the family structure, but which, ladies and gentlemen, violates the principle of subsidiarity that, in education and health, the competences of each Member State must be respected.

name: Rosa ESTARÀS FERRAGUT
text: – Mr President, there is no doubt that equal opportunities is a challenge, it is an objective, it is a mission for all of us sitting in this House. It is not the heritage of any political party: neither of the right, nor of the left, nor of the center. We are all committed to the values of the European Union, and the maximum value is the value of equality between all and that of non-discrimination. It is true that the Strategy we had raised in 2010-2015 now ends and a new strategy is needed, because there is a long way to go. Above all, in order to end discrimination and, above all, to address the main labour challenges. There is still, for work of equal value, an average wage discrimination of 16.5%. This is also a grievance in pensions and also assumes that women are not occupying managerial positions, but are basically co-orfied by the male gender. It also means that you have to work to break stereotypes and educate on equality, which means co-educate. It means educating in values and betting on inclusive education. We must also bet on ending gender-based violence. It is the greatest attack on human rights, and a consequence of inequality.
