Any type of gender-based violence — whether physical, psychic, material, sexual... of any kind—it is undoubtedly a consequence of the lack of educating on that equality, and that is why we will have to work hard and we will have to do everything in our power to prevent, to be able to work when there is gender-based violence, to be announced, to leave the private sphere and to be persecuted relentlessly. It is true that, when there was a crisis, poverty has a symbol of women. Poverty is, it remains, especially feminine, and the most vulnerable sectors, such as single women, immigrants, disabled women, older women, ethnic minorities, and LGBT groups are also the most affected. We are all united in this struggle and, therefore, what I would ask on the left is that, if you really care about these very important goals, separate the issue of abortion, which is where we are created by a division, and work on what uniessotes us. (She agreed to answer a question posed under the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Regulation))

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: blue-card question. – I enjoyed the presentation by our colleague, Ms Estaràs Ferragut. I would like to ask her – because she mentioned stereotypes and domestic violence – whether new forms of violence against women, such as those found in social media, are also an urgent matter that needs to be dealt with?

name: Rosa ESTARÀS FERRAGUT
text: "blue card" response. – Very timely appreciation, Mr Frunzulic. Indeed, the whole issue of innovation and new technologies has brought new forms of gender-based violence, such as "cyber bullying," as well as all that is network harassment. In fact, it is an issue that in schools is creating a great deal of concern and there has already been, in Spain and in many countries of the Union, even some cases that have reached suicide.  Therefore, gender-based violence is not only, as in the past, physical: it can be psychic; can be done with new technologies; it may be this harassment I've explained to you; it can be material; can be sexual. And you have to fight all its forms.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: Mr President, three months ago we adopted my report on gender equality. The report proposed ambitious measures included in the Noichl report. In particular, we called on the European Commission to establish 2016 as the European Year to Combat Violence Against Women. This request was further confirmed by the written declaration which we have successfully adopted through the mobilization of Members, which I thank again. My colleague Noichl's report is yet another request to the Commission to take further measures to effectively combat violence against women. I therefore call on the Commission to finally respond to our demands with concrete measures. I would like to conclude by calling on my colleagues from all sides of the political party to support Mrs Noichl's report. We must take to the letter the European motto: 'Unite in Diversity'.  This report may not be perfect for some of you, but here and now it is the European Parliament that is in favour of women's rights and it is Mrs Noichl's report that is the most ambitious and concrete.  You who supported my report three months ago thank you for doing the same for my colleague, Mrs Noichl' report.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: – Despite many necessary recommendations, the proposal again seeks to interfere unacceptably with the exclusive competences of the Member States. In order to promote abortion as a human right, it omines the very primary human right, that is, the right to life and its protection from conception. Nor does it respect other fundamental human rights, such as the right to consetion, especially among doctors. It does not respect the exclusive right of parents to raise their children. It unacceptably interferes with the private sphere of families when it wants to dictate to them how to share family competences. Europe already has experience in social engineering – it has always been disastrous. No law can dictate the distribution of domestic work or the number of women in companies. It is inefficient bureaucracy and EU intervention in areas where nothing is to be ordered. The report neglects the fundamental importance of informal family work carried out mainly by women, whether it is the care of dependent family members and whether investments in human capital are still underestimated. They are irreplaceable for the whole of society. It is absurd that the report for equality between women and men completely neglects this fact.

name: Yana TOOM
text: – Mr President, lack of substantial equality in various areas of social life is still a problem for women all over Europe. In the labour market they still earn less than men on average. In most places they are under-represented at the top of the career ladder and over-represented in the less prestigious sectors of the economy. A woman’s potential is limited by the unequal distribution of household labour. However, I would like to single out the widespread problem of domestic violence. A major problem for the investigation of domestic violence cases is the reluctance of victims to report such cases to the authorities. Often the reluctance to report is linked to a lack of faith in the ability of law enforcement to deal with these issues. A lack of shelters, and financial dependence on offenders, is a further problem. The persistence of stereotypes concerning the roles and responsibilities of women and men in the family and in society is another challenge. In some countries, obstacles to dealing with cases of domestic violence may be related to the fact that they are cases for private prosecution. Many Member States have no specific criminal provisions on domestic violence and marital rape, and rape is prosecuted within the framework of a private prosecution. Abolishing private prosecution in cases of domestic violence and rape may contribute to better protection of victims of crime. Estonia, my own country, is a good example in this context. We need a comprehensive fight against domestic violence at EU level. Therefore, I would stress the importance of the recommendation to designate a European Year for combating violence against women and girls.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: – Mr President, first of all I would like to thank the rapporteur for the work of the rapporteur of this report, with which we intend from the FEMM Commission to help develop a common European strategy on equality. Commissioner, we are here to hear you listen to us, as you said in January, to build on our work, and that is why we are presenting this report which asks the European Union to go far beyond the 2010-2015 Strategy, which has not exactly been very successful. But, having said that, I would like to point out that we need to better address two aspects that are fundamental: on the one hand, prostitution, because we understand that turning sex into a commodity only serves to perpetuate patriarchal culture. Women are often subjugated and conditioned by extreme poverty, if not forced by mafias. That's why we can't agree to talk about one prostitution better than another. And with regard to the origin of gender inequality, I do not understand why this Parliament is so afraid, and this right here in this Parliament, to talk about the origin of it. None of our amendments have been accepted and it must be said that austerity measures following the crisis have exacerbated the feminization of poverty.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: – Indirect or indirect discrimination occurs when a state decision is not explicitly discriminatory at first sight, but its effect affects one sex, mostly women, rather than the other as a negative effect.  Typically, such indirect discrimination is carried out when, say, one government in Hungary decides after another – most recently this one – not to give nurses, nursery workers, teachers, social workers a pay rise, not to increase their income, but even ten years after we join the European Union, the Hungarian State is in a shameful situation where a nurse or a social worker earns the equivalent of EUR 300. They believe that women will not rebel against this, because it is mostly women, because it is mostly women.  But they did rebel, they're on the streets, they're protesting. I call on you to support them regardless of party affiliation, and I also ask that this issue be taken up by the European Parliament. Thank you very much!

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: – The Universal Declaration of Human Rights says: "All people are born free and equal in dignity and rights." All people – women as well as men. But this equality is not, and cannot be, understood as an equal. The report presented goes far beyond the Treaties. It is a new and worse variation on the infamous Estrela report, which wants to adopt the powers of the Member States. It is thanks to such manifestations of godly ignorance that distrust of the European Union is growing among people. Because you can't trust someone who takes every opportunity to keep a valid agreement. According to the draft vote, there is even a risk that the right of children to know their parents, which is also enshrined in the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child, is even in danger of falling out of the text, which is also enshrined in the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child, with the report containing requirements for the extension of artificial insemination services for everyone and the legalisation of surrogacy between the lines. This report imposes disrespect on human life and dignity on the citizens of the Member States. It imposes on them the illusion of equality and rights that are not balanced by responsibility. It imposes on them social engineering based on a gender ideology that denies and seeks to censor both natural sciences and human sciences. Although there are a number of paragraphs in this report that I would like to support, I must reject it, and I believe that, together with me, it will be rejected by anyone who can still use their moral compass. All we can do tomorrow is to downste the evil and vote in favour of an alternative resolution.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Mr President, I would like to thank my colleague Maria Noichl for the report and also all the men who have spoken in support of these progressive amendments today. Tomorrow’s vote will determine much of the EU’s gender equality strategy for years to come, affecting the lives of more than 250 million women and also 250 million men, and I am proud to be a good mother to two of them. From this Chamber we must issue a strong and ambitious call for action in view of a reality where one out of three women suffers from physical or sexual violence, the largest-scale violation of human rights in Europe. That is a reality we simply cannot accept. We need to have a clear strategy supporting victims of violence and providing access to justice, and to have Member States in the EU implement the Istanbul Convention on combating violence against women. We must also address the social causes of violence. We must call upon Member States to implement strategies on education for gender equality and for sex and relationship education. Educating children and young people to respect one another, educating for reciprocity and consent, is the key to combating the sexist cultural attitudes that enable violence. We must call for education against gender stereotypes, homophobia and transphobia. The representation of women in the media, in culture and in the arts is also crucial for combating violence and for gender equality in general, empowering women through positive role models, raising awareness of the diversity of gender roles, telling the stories of survivors of violence and of women’s success stories in the fields of science, technology, business and society at large. We must also look to raise awareness and hear the stories of women in marginalised communities and their daily struggles: women asylum seekers, migrants, women in rural communities, Roma, minority women, women with disabilities, women in rural communities, carers, LGBTI, and women with mental health conditions. Any gender equality strategy must include all of these.

name: Marek JUREK
text: – Abortionism is now the most influential, unfortunately, and most abhorrent ideology of discrimination. Unfortunately, this ideology is also poisoning this report, with paragraphs 52 and 68 clearly in favour of this perspective. Meanwhile, there are millions of women living in Europe who want to be respected in their vocation to motherhood, who want to be respected and want to be supported. By the way, let me share the research we have carried out in our country. They have clearly shown that a typical abortion advocate is a young, rich, lonely man, not a young, poor, manly woman. Let us defend the right to children, but let us also defend the right to women and respect in what, above all, is fulfilled by their natural predisposition – motherhood.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: Mr President, at a time when the peoples of Europe are suffering from a migration flood and are sinking into economic stagnation, and the geopolitical perils are worsening, this Parliament seems to be prioritising gender ideology and Community demands. Once again, and under the guise of great universal principles, we are offered a most sectarian political manifesto to justify the destruction of natural and traditional institutions. It is children who are targeted through medically assisted reproduction and the unrestrained promotion of abortion. More serious and even more shocking: these positions are defended in the name of health and the fight against infertility, a pernicious argument seeking to generalize these practices of manipulation of life and insidiously opening the door to gestation on behalf of others, the last act of the suppression of parentage and the elementary rights of the child. By pretending to defend women, you will turn the poorest of them into procreating machines. Here, then, appears the true face of a decadence organized in the name of a libertarian liberal utopia.

name: Lara COMI
text: Thank you, Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, once again we are faced with an attempt to use a report and an issue as important as equality between men and women, forcing certain concepts that cannot be shared. Some of my fellow Members say that the progress and development of man and of our society must be based on the recognition of the right to abortion as a fundamental human right, through the modification of the concept of parenthood beyond natural law, through the support of sexual and reproductive health, without, however, explaining what the limits really are, how far we can go.  I do not agree, and I think I really do represent the thinking of a large number of European citizens, that it does not explain why Parliament is doing so much to support these issues, even forcing in some cases the division of competence between the European Union and the Member States, and not giving certain and effective answers to the real problems that it is experiencing. , man and woman and the relationship of equality between men and women in daily life. So let's really all ask ourselves where we're going and try to re-establish the right priorities, the right goals of real support and progress of the man and the society in which we live. So let us not find shortcuts so as not to tackle the real problem of everyday life.  I support, of course, the PPE's motion for a resolution, which I believe to be balanced in highlighting the main problems facing our political action and solving them. I call on all members of the other groups to read it with great, great care and to consider supporting it. In my speech, I did not highlight the problem that so many other Members have raised about children. Here I believe that perhaps in order to protect them often we must also return a little children, to understand how we live even with realities that are sometimes too extreme.

name: Inés AYALA SENDER
text: – Madam President, I would like to congratulate the rapporteur on her rather balanced and fairly continuing report with what this House has been doing. I don't understand that tearing of the garments or the alternative resolution that goes - say - to the extreme, back to the past. The current Strategy is coming to an end and has so far been a very useful tool in terms of economic independence, equal pay, equality in decision-making, an end to sexist violence and equality in external action.   There has been a lack of resources, as always: the European Union is never sufficiently budgeted for the great ambitions that its citizens demand of us. Impact capacity was also limited, as there were no deadlines, fewer objectives or more concrete indicators. Even the European road safety strategy is most effective in setting its objectives and mechanisms for achieving this. We are not able to do so, starting with the elimination of sexist violence against women from daily life - which reduces wages and prevents motherhood from being raised or not in a totally free way - to the extremes of human trafficking and enslavement in prostitution or femicides that we do not even know or can encrypt because the European Union has not yet managed to give an homologable and comparable definition in order to be able to address and avoid them. That is why we need a new European strategy to help us combat the tremendous impact of the economic crisis on the radical impoverishment of women, to help us effectively and urgently address the diversity of discrimination against women with disabilities, immigrants, because of their ethnic status, Roma, the elderly...  We therefore need European women to remain leaders within the European Union to grow in rights outside our borders with the rest of the women in the world and thus help and help ourselves, European women at last.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: – Madam President, I regret that the report by MEP Marija Noichl, who is tasked with giving recommendations and guidance to the European Commission, regarding the improvement of equality between men and women for the new post-2015 strategy has again served individual groups to promote their radical and ideological demands. I find it inadmissible that this Parliament has another report on the agenda that encroaches on the competence of member states, undermines a family based on marriage between a man and a woman, and directly promotes abortion as a human right. According to the definition of sexual and reproductive rights of the Beijing platform celebrating the twentieth anniversary, in no case can abortion be promoted as a method of family planning. It is scandalous that this report encourages the European Union to use development aid money to fund abortions and sterilisation of women in poor countries around the world, rather than provide them with education and self-employment. The report promotes gender ideology and encourages the adoption of regulations that will lead to discrimination against private entrepreneurs, especially those in the service sector, which is unacceptable.  This report is irreparable. Therefore, the European People's Party Group has submitted an alternative resolution calling for ensuring equality between men and women in the field of labour and social rights, access to education and the labour market, ensuring access to health and promoting women's participation in responsible decision-making positions.  I invite you to stand up for true equality between women and men in all segments of life and to support women and men who choose to start a family and have children because family is the first school of interpersensal relationships, a place where they teach us equality and values. Family is a place where we are taught what kind of people we need to be and that is why it would be important to support the family in the European Parliament.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: – Madam President, I congratulate the rapporteur on her approach, which is intended to respond to existing challenges. Twenty years after the adoption of the objectives of the Beijing Platform for Action, we note that the commendable intention of decision-makers to implement gender equality in all areas of life is not being implemented at the desired pace and all the objectives aimed at genuine gender equality have not yet been achieved at European level. And we could exemplify with the right to integrity and a dignified life, but also with a better distribution of childcare tasks and the full use of talents and qualifications. On the other hand, we must not forget that, in the European Union, around 42% of the actors regularly involved in agriculture are women, and three out of ten farms at European level are managed by women. The European Commission together with the Member States must contribute to the promotion of a strategy leading to job creation for women in rural areas and, by implication, to the provision of decent pensions for retiring women in the European Union who live in precarious conditions, many working or working in agriculture and who do not have pensions or whose pensions are very low. I will vote on this report because I believe that a long-term strategy and a response that the vast majority of women expect from us is needed.

name: Seán KELLY
text: –  A Uachtaráin, ní hé seo an chéad uair go bhfuilimid ag caint faoin ábhar seo. Faraor, ní hé an uair dheireanach ach oiread mar tá sé soiléir go bhfuil go leor le déanamh chun cothromaíocht idir na gnéis a bhaint amach san Aontas.  Dá bhrí sin, is trua nach féidir linn glacadh leis an tuarascáil seo d’aon ghuth, mar a dúirt mo chomhghleacaithe, de bharr go bhfuil rudaí ann nach mbaineann linn cosúil le ginmhilleadh, cúrsaí sláinte, cúrsaí traenála, agus cúrsaí oideachais; rudaí a bhaineann leis na Ballstáit. Bíodh sin mar atá, ba mhaith liom díriú ar mo thír féin, Éire, anois. Ireland ranks slightly above the European average in the Gender Equality Index. In some areas we are good and in some areas we are not too good. For instance, in our national parliament, only 27 of the 166 TDs are female. As a result of that, in next year’s elections, parties will have to have 30% females among their candidates. On the other hand, here in Brussels and Strasbourg, six of our eleven MEPs are women, and indeed, 12 of the 14 in the island of Ireland are women. So things are improving in some respects and not in others. At the same time, some of the most powerful positions in Ireland are held by women: Tánaiste (Deputy Prime Minister), Minister for Justice, Attorney General, Chief Justice, Director of Public Prosecutions (DPP) and Garda Commissioner. The European Ombudsman, Emily O’Reilly, is an Irishwoman and two of our last three Presidents,  Mary McAleese and Mary Robinson, were excellent Presidents. That shows that, if women are given the opportunity, they can do the job. So that is something we need to work on. However, one area which we are not happy about is that, perhaps because of the recession, the pay gap between men and women has widened in Ireland to 14.4%. That is something that must be addressed as a matter of urgency.

name: Iliana IOTOVA
text: – Thank you, Madam President, I would like to congratulate Maria Neuchen on the excellent work done. For the first time in a long time, we have a clear and firm document, with a bold vision of politics, with bold solutions that we need to defend this week with our vote.  In this debate, however, we must be honest enough. Progress on equality between women and men is very weak. Good strategies and suggestions are declarative, we wear them like a beautiful brooch on the lapel, but we do not implement them. No one can convince us of our concern as long as the Maternity Directive continues to travel between institutions. No one can convince while one in three women has been subjected to violence, and we continue to argue about exactly what year to devote to fighting violence. No one can convince, while women get much lower wages, much lower pensions, much less are at work. No strategy will work as we turn a blind eye to the fact that more and more women are working in the black, in the informal economy, without contracts and elementary protection. No one will believe us if we talk about sovereignty and subsidiarity, but in fact we deny women rights.  Today, efforts are focused on rescue operations for the thousands of refugees at the European Union's external borders.  But there have been increased reports of thousands of female refugees working for miserable pay to save their families. Reports of secondary trafficking of women and girls already on European territory have also increased. If we don't have adequate solutions today, it'il be too late tomorrow. The feminisation of poverty is the definite history of work of both European institutions and Member States. And that is why it is important to support the Neuchen report – a good start for bold solutions.

name: Anna Maria CORAZZA BILDT
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for We have credible reports that violence against women is being used as a weapon of war in eastern Ukraine – sexual violence – it is happening in Europe today. Now that we are devising a European gender equality strategy, we shall first of all concentrate on zero tolerance for violence against women and girls. These are men's violence against women, domestic violence, sexual exploitation, honour killings and much more.  It is time for European legislation that criminalises, prevents and combats these terrible crimes to be complied with. Member States must implement the Directive on trafficking and the protection of victims of crime and the European Protection Order. Member States must adopt the Council of Europe's Istanbul Convention on Violence against Women. As long as violence is tolerated, we will never achieve equality. I would also particularly welcome the fact that – outside Europe – Nigeria has now adopted a total ban on female genital mutilation.  Member States should also focus on increasing women's access to work without discrimination in order to erase the pay gap, which is still wide. It is jobs and economic independence that are the way to independence, not least for migrant women. Several women are going to work, several women will dare to start their own business. It is crucial for europe's economy. We must also make it easier for women to promote shared responsibility for children, so that women and men have the same opportunity to combine family and career. But maternity leave should be parental leave and family policy is a national matter.  It is clear to me that women should have the right to control their bodies. All women should have safe access to sexual and reproductive health and rights. I regret that some Greens have kidnapped the issue of gender equality. We must move on from old-fashioned red ideology that is stuck in the rhetoric of the seventies about patriarchy and women's struggle. Our women's struggle is a fight for freedom and dignity.

name: Clare MOODY
text: – Madam President, in paragraph 64 this report calls for compliance with gender equality to be considered a criterion for all EU-funded culture, education and research programmes and asks the Commission to include a specific area of gender research within the Horizon 2020 programme. We know that women are severely under-represented in science, technology, research and the digital sector. For example, and I quote, ‘often there are more iPADs in the room than there are women’. It is shameful. In the UK women make up under 30% of the information and communications technology workforce, comprising around 20% of computing graduates and 10% of app developers. There is forecast to be a labour shortage of STEM (science, technology, engineering and mathematics) jobs of around 7 million by 2025, and women only make up 24% of science and engineering professionals. We know this is because women drop out of STEM and IT subjects very early in the education process. Female participation in IT apprenticeship programmes and computer science degrees is only 21% and 19% respectively. In secondary education, where girls choose their own subjects, only 8% of girls in the UK choose computer studies. So the EU has a social, moral and economic duty to ensure a gender focus and equal gender participation in STEM sectors. More women in science and technology is good for the economy. It is good for society and, above all, it is the right thing to do because it gives women and girls a choice about how they want to lead their lives. The EU can help to achieve this in this report today by voting for it and ensuring gender issues are mainstreamed in the Horizon 2020 programme.

name: József NAGY
text: - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support. Today, when the pay gap in the EU is on average 16% due to the fact that someone is doing a job as a man or a woman; at a time when we should be helping or intrempressing female leaders into public life or economic positions with quotas, and when we have to debate whether to recognise a mother's right to motherhood, or to punish her if she wants to go on maternity leave, then, ladies and gentlemen, I find it insakent that some political groups are bringing in inappropriate issues in the shadow of this important political issue. It's a distraction. That is why I cannot support a report that has been distorted in this direction, because it is precisely these non-subjects that are deliberately impeding the report itself.  As an EU strategy, I expect concrete steps for equality between women and men, focusing primarily on equal opportunities in economic and public life, recognition, acceptance and translation of differences between the two sexes for the benefit of society. We're not robots, and we don't want to put uniforms on everyone. We are men and women who must all be given the opportunity to prevail. It is time for our strategy not to be made up of nebulous concepts, but a series of concrete steps for a Europe based on real equality of opportunity.  I can therefore only support the amended proposal tabled on behalf of the PpE Group. Thank you very much!

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: – Madam President, first I would like to thank my colleague Noichl for her excellent work and appreciation of the contribution of a large number of colleagues. The latest gender equality strategy has not yielded significant results and that is why I consider it necessary for this one to be more ambitious. Achieving gender equality is a precondition for achieving the general objectives of the European Union, such as increasing employment, reducing the wage gap. I decided to put in amendments myself that called for easier access to funding for projects for female entrepreneurs. However, I think it is not right to concentrate only on the economic approach to gender equality, so I also asked for amendments regarding sex education in schools in order to combat prejudice and gender inequalities as successfully as possible. The question now is: will we support a proposal that is a proposal for several political options of the European Parliament and which was adopted by the competent parliamentary committee or a subsequent alternative proposal of one political option. We MEPs are obliged to take decisions that have a very concrete positive impact on the lives of all citizens, rather than the kind of proposals that we know in advance will be a dead letter on paper. The alternative proposal is nothing more than a bureaucratic document that neither harms nor benefits, and does not include some of the most important dimensions of the fight for gender equality such as reducing violence against women, taking into account groups facing double discrimination, e.g. the disabled, Roma women, migrant women, etc. Furthermore, this proposal completely ignores the fact that the European Union should be an example in the world with its value system, from which news of horrific crimes against girls and women comes every day. As a shadow rapporteur for the budget, I am particularly saddened that the European People's Party has not recognised the importance of budget planning or in reference to binding legislative acts. That leaves everything an empty story. Here we determine the position of women in the next five-year period and that is why I support colleague Noichl's proposal. (The Speaker agreed to answer the question by raising the blue card on the basis of Article 162(8) of the Code of Health. Rules of procedure.)

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". I do not know whether you have read the PPE and ECR report at all. But what would interest me is that we are constantly talking about a wage gap or a 16% pay gap. Do you know that mothers have a 40% pay gap? Has this 40% pay gap been taken into account in any way in Mrs Noichl's report? Or is motherhood something that belongs in the Middle Ages?

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: answer to the question posed by raising the blue card. – I absolutely do not consider that mothers and motherhood are something that belongs to the Middle Ages and of course it can still be determined in each Member State that mothers and motherhood are determined by that amount of money as well as for men.  Therefore, this strategy does not have to contain all the details, but details can be determined in national parliaments and in all Member States individually.

name: Romana TOMC
text: – Thank you very much for your word. In my speech, I will focus on a very important area for me, which I believe is not yet fully achieved, and it is also one of those areas where we could make progress relatively quickly. It is about women's participation in entrepreneurship and it is about women taking up leadership positions in the economy.  It is unacceptable that there are still huge differences in the involvement of men and women when it comes to meeting those really highest, most important places where the most important decisions are made. The fact is that Europeans have a higher level of education compared to their male counterparts. And also various studies show that a balance between women and men in leadership positions can lead to an improvement in European competitiveness and, of course, to a better position in international markets. But why doesn't that happen? If we really want to make progress, we need to make shifts in the education system itself. It is the education system that must be focused on promoting entrepreneurship and, in general, breaking down the stereotype of so-called male bosses.  Stereotypical leadership still prevails in the business world, in politics and in our society as a whole. And I believe that both the European Commission and the European Parliament have done a great deal, and I hope that the Council will also find an appropriate solution and continue negotiations on the Women on board directive.   Of course, responsibility always lies primarily with the Member States themselves, and it is obvious that the quota system gives certain results, even though I have quite a few concerns about it.

name: Péter NIEDERMÜLLER
text: – First of all, I would like to thank the author of this excellent and forward-looking report. You all know that gender equality is one of the fundamental values of the European Union. That is why discrimination against women, violence against women, women's poverty in old age, these are european issues, not simply problems in the Member States. Although the principle of subsidiarity can be invoked, these remain European problems, the problems of European societies.  We need a forward-looking report, not one that tries to hide social problems behind pathetic anachronisms. We must face up to the fact that discrimination against women particularly severely affects those who are marginalised, who live in poverty, who not only suffer discrimination against women, but are also discriminated against, for example, in relation to their ethnicity. I am thinking, for example, of Roma women, of women in poor queues who are under-qualified, who do not have adequate qualifications and therefore have little or no access to work, or, if they get a job, in humiliating conditions.  I think we need a new strategy, a new way of thinking. There is a need to pay particular attention to women with disabilities, older women, migrant women, LGBT communities, Roma. In this area, the European Commission should strive to create new education and inclusion programmes. Only in this way can discrimination against women of all kinds be eliminated within the European Union. It is not possible to forget people who live in difficult situations and poverty. There is therefore a need for quality education, access to child-rearing and other social support systems, and specific special programmes. Without it, we won't be able to bring order. Thank you very much!

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: – Madam President, more than thirty-five years after the UNITED NATIONS Convention on the elimination of all forms of discrimination against women, we are still defining strategies to ensure equity between them and men in the European Union. It is, in fact, regrettable.  Nevertheless, while I recognise that the report we are discussing is ambitious, I believe that it goes out of its objectives and calls into question the principle of subsidiarity, which has to be taken into account in the final vote.  Commissioner, while I recognise the Union's progress on gender equality, and the proof of this is that we both have the opportunity to be here in this Parliament to discuss this issue, there is still a long way to go.  I do not think we should treat as equal what is different because it is not by giving the same to everyone that we are being fair, but by adapting to the needs of each one. This, in my view, is the new paradigm of gender equity. I therefore argue that men and women have the same basic rights, such as access to work with fair pay, equal work-equal income, access to political life, work-life balance, among other aspects.  But allow me, Commissioner, to highlight what, in my view, is the key to all this, to allow the annulment of these inequalities. I'm obviously talking about education. Knowledge is power and, therefore, I believe that the European Union has a duty to create all the conditions of access to education, training and information for all women and men, so that stereotypes and prejudices that become, throughout its life, the rightto be castters of the integral development of the human person, which enhance abuses of the most varied order. By endeaunion of young people with these tools, we will be contributing to an equitable society.  It is in this sense that I believe that all the instruments available to the Union and the Member States must be put into practice, such as the Istanbul Convention, because physical, verbal, psychological, religious, financial violence, among others, is still a sad reality.  Women count on us, not the ones sitting here, but the ones no one hears about: the victims of the system.  There's still a lot to do.

name: Soraya POST
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for I would like to start by saying that I have not been here from the start, but what I have heard is, of course, purely anti-feminist policies being pursued from this side and that is totally unacceptable in a modern Europe in 2015. We need a new gender equality strategy that aims forward to the future and the values that we in Europe should stand for. Then we are not talking about legitimised discrimination on the grounds of sex, as we have been doing all along, because that is exactly what is going on: legitimising discrimination on the basis of sex. If we do not want it, if we want to talk about equality, then we should also talk about discrimination on the basis of gender.  I think the report is very good and Would like to thank you for that. It therefore contains an understanding of gender equality that does not lock itself into dealing with women and men, but focuses on the relationships that create inequality between women and men and those that do not fit into any of these categories. It is important that there should be a strategy for women's rights and gender equality in Europe.  I am pleased that the report highlights the fact that successful gender equality work must be based on the living conditions of different groups of women. The aim of the new gender equality strategy must be gender equality for all women, at all levels, and men in Europe, including women with disabilities, women with a migration background, LGBTQ women, Roma women, minorities and people in exclusion.  I think that the report puts the work on gender equality in a broader mri perspective. That is what they are about, it is about human rights. What one spoke of earlier: a true policy on equality, while denying the woman the right to abortion, the right to decide over her own body, it is appalling. I think that the EPP has gone backwards in its own motion. They are going backwards and they are going against what Parliament has adopted in the past for a policy on gender equality in which we really see that women and men are equal.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: – The issue of equality between people before and against the law is one of the most important challenges facing humanity. The European Union has a leading role in achieving this humanist objective. At the same time, however, we must deal with the inequalities that prevail in the Member States themselves. This also applies to inequalities and even discrimination against women. Firstly, I think that we will not be able to cope with all sorts of inequalities between women and men without strengthening education. Education and education should therefore be the strongest tools for combating prejudice, stereotypes, but also the consequences of perceiving this issue through the lens of a false tradition or religion. Secondly, however, politicians face the most important challenge. Indeed, if conservative forces block civilisational change, we will not achieve optimal results for equality between women and men, especially in the short term. It is therefore up to the politicians, especially in the individual Member States, to take this task on their own shoulders. The third and final issue in this synthetic speech – the area where radical changes should take place – is the labour market: employment, including women's wages, and flexibility in working time. There will be no equality if women cannot self-pursue themselves in a 21st century society to the same extent as men. I therefore think that this strategy for equality between women and men, in most of its provisions, is well addressing the challenges I have identified. (The speaker agreed to answer the blue card question (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Neena GILL
text: blue-card question. – I agree with you, Mr Szejnfeld, that educating children and young people is key to achieving gender equality, and especially to ending violence against women. Teaching boys and girls to respect one another is really important. But do you not think that the representation of women and of girls and boys in the media is also a problem, and that we need to address that at the same time as having policies addressing education? In other words, do we not need to address both these things as a priority?

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: answer to the question asked by raising the blue card. – I am convinced that education should be treated and understood widely in this matter. It is not just about education for children and young people, although in this respect I am convinced and my knowledge suggests to me that in many Member States of the European Union we do not have a good enough level of education. But this education must apply not only to children and young people. It must apply to all societies regardless of age, because it is precisely these stereotypes, those found from the past and traditions, sometimes also from religions, that have and are rooted in people who are of different ages.

name: Virginie ROZIÈRE
text: Madam President, they spend twice as much time as men taking care of household chores and taking care of children, their pay is always lower than that of men, their rights are regularly questioned and a third of them have already suffered sexual and physical violence. That is what the situation of women in the European Union is today. Abortion, LDCs for all couples, sex education, maternity leave reform are all advanced solutions to fight inequality and prejudice! In this, Maria Noichl's text is a progressive text. A little too progressive for some, perhaps, since an alternative resolution is tabled by the EPP Group and this resolution looks back on fundamental advances for women: no reference to gender equality, no budgetary commitment, no reference to abortion. In short, these are all setbacks for women, even on one of the most identified issues: women's employment and working conditions. Conservatives who deny women full control of their sexual and reproductive rights, maneuver and misinform. They use the pretext of LDC and abortion to justify their refusal to improve the status of women and their integration into the professional world.  While they are increasingly present in the labour market, inequalities remain numerous: wages are lower than men's, jobs are less skilled, women have fewer responsibilities and more part-time work. To this, it should be added that women's unemployment remains higher than that of men, especially when they have dependent children. Even as a couple, access to work remains the best bulwark against poverty. Finally, women in the world of work are more likely to experience disqualification than men because, even with a high degree, many of them are in jobs that do not correspond to their training. That is why a European Union strategy on equality is needed and that is why it is desirable and happy that this report proposes the introduction of more flexible forms of work, so that men and women can better balance work and family life.  After the vote on Marc Tarabella's report, let us hope that this report will mark another step for the European Union in favour of women's rights.

name: Michela GIUFFRIDA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, this House has often debated women's rights. Unfortunately, the reality that forces us to face the debate is clear to everyone: maternity leave, genital mutilation, violence, the wage gap, sexual and reproductive rights are just some of the debates that have shown how urgent it is to develop a strategy for equality between men and women, a strategy to be followed up by well-defined political actions, which has practical repercussions , convient and effective. I do not believe that one or more laws are enough to change things: they are important in guaranteeing rights, rights that are often ignored, but what is needed above all is cultural development, which can only start with education and training, but for this we need funds, resources and not just good intentions. Finally, since equality is not achieved by means of a regulation, we must educate our male and female children in mutual respect. We have to work for that thank you.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: – Madam President, I strongly support the adoption of a new, separate strategy on gender equality and women’s rights in the European Union. It is especially important to prioritise the fight against violence against women. New forms of violence against women, such as those found in social media, are also an urgent matter that needs to be dealt with. We should be very active on combating violence, tackling pay gaps and on ensuring that women can reach equal positions in the working world. I especially support the new approaches introduced in the report for reconciliation of private and professional life to be dealt with, with a strong focus on care and working-time arrangements. I thank the rapporteur and the shadow rapporteur for the great job they have done, and I am sure it will have a very positive outcome for our societies in the future.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Madam President, in today's economic climate, effective implementation of gender equality policy is a top political priority. In the countries of the European South, mercelial austerity has led women to poverty and social marginalisation.  In Greece according to official data, 60% of the registered unemployed in the OAED are women and amount to five hundred and eighteen thousand. At the same time, however, only 15.7% of these unemployed women receive unemployment benefit. Also, while women's unemployment in 2009, before the Memorandum, was 14.4 %, in 2014 the figure has risen to 29.3% . Moreover, the pay gap between men and women has increased considerably .  The dismantling of the public sector and the imposition of flexible forms of employment has brought many women to economic despair. Inequalities between men and women have negative consequences for societies themselves and because of these inequalities these societies are now unable to create sustainable development and social cohesion.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: – Madam President, I was looking forward to receiving information that this report was accepted by a majority vote in the committee responsible because it meant that we would finally accept here, in this Parliament, this report which speaks above all about the fundamental values of the European Union, about equality between a woman and a man, about the freedom to which every person, individual, is entitled.  Unfortunately here we see obvious differences today and using the argument of ideologies, so of course everyone has their own ideology and we are all different and we all belong to different political parties and we carry our ideas, but we have accepted some things jointly on the committee. On the other hand, when we talk about subsidiarity, I am one of those people who thinks that perhaps the best thing would be to solve things locally or regionally. That is why the principle of subsidiarity cannot be accepted because more fundamental freedoms for me than subsidiarity are equality and freedom.

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: – Madam President, we talk about equality post 2015. Let me take you back to a time when a young girl grew up during the Second World War in England. She was from a lower class background than most of the rulers we have ever had in England. She grew up to win a record number of elections in our country; she defeated the hard left in our country; she defeated the Soviet Union and won the Cold War. She went on to fight for liberty and freedom and, at every step of the way, Margaret Thatcher never once had an EU directive or a helping hand or a quota. So, in the spirit of freedom that Mrs Thatcher put forward, when you speak of gender quotas for business, sex education and PC indoctrination in schools, and the amount of housework that men should do being dictated from here, well, as the lady would say, ‘No, no, no!’

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, the European Parliament has always been a driver – and an important partner for change – for gender equality. In today’s discussion on Ms Noichl’s report I heard here a powerful voice on the necessity of a strong and comprehensive EU policy to promote equality between women and men. I count on your support to continue our journey towards an equal Europe, and I reiterate the Commission’s strong commitment to equality between women and men, backed by concrete policy actions.

name: Maria NOICHL
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her When women's right to vote was introduced, was it gender ideology, or was it progress? When women were allowed to run an account on their own – was it gender ideology, or was it progress? When marital rape was finally called a criminal offence, was it gender ideology, or was it progress? These thoughts came to mind today when I really had to hear speeches here that I believed to have been a thing of the past for a long time. I have an appeal to you and I make a very clear appeal to the EPP and to other Conservatives here in the House. I appeal to you: be honest with your constituents! Be honest! It is an own-initiative motion, it is not a legislative motion! Be honest! It is not immediately transposed into national law, but it is a message. It is a message that comes from this House. And be honest, don't say things that are never in the report! I have heard the word surrogacy on several occasions today. At no point or at any minute has surrogacy been discussed in the rapporteur's meetings, or even written into the report. Be honest when it comes to that! I have seen today that ideology is on your side, not on our side. However, I also have an appeal to all my fellow Members in this House: with the result of 20 votes in favour and 12 against, the report was adopted in committee – it is no longer my report alone, but it is our report. I appeal to you tomorrow to reject the PPE-DE alternative resolution and vote on the report, which has been developed jointly for months. And I have an appeal to you, Commissioner: the report is the basis for you, and then the work begins in your House. Then the work begins in your House for the Commission to set out with a strategy. And I would like to give you every support you need from this side, from my side, but also from the entire FEMM Committee. The report here, which is adopted by the citizens of Europe, is the first step. The second step is the report that comes from your House. I hope that we will take the first step tomorrow, and then it will be in your hands.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: The debate is over.  The vote will take place tomorrow, Tuesday, June 9, 2015. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. – Despite the various documents adopted in the area of gender equality, women in Europe, both young and older, still face many problems. Gender equality and non-discrimination on grounds of sex are still a challenge in our work. Unfortunately, in Europe, poverty is mainly at risk for women, particularly single mothers, young and elderly women suffering from poverty and social exclusion, and the situation is exacerbated by the economic crisis and special austerity measures. The situation is also exacerbated by precarious work, part-time work, low wages and pensions, difficulties in accessing basic social and health services, job creation, particularly in the public sector and services in the care and nursing sector, making this gender equality approach even more important. We therefore call on the Commission to develop and adopt a new separate European strategy on women's rights and gender equality aimed at creating equal opportunities in order to eliminate all discrimination against women in the labour market, wages, pensions, decision-making, access to goods and services, reconciliation of family life and work, etc. It is also necessary to put an end to all forms of violence against women, and we are again calling on the Commission to come forward with a legislative proposal to combat violence against girls and women and to prevent violence.

name: Aymeric CHAUPRADE
text: In writing. This Noichl report, which was delivered by the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality, is in line with the Estrella, Tarabella and Panzeri reports that the European Parliament has been feeding us in recent years. The victimization of women observed in these reports serves a mortal ideology whose purpose is actually to defeminize the woman, to take away her essence. Thus, the Noichl report prefers to reduce women to a production capital, to a simple economic fact that it is a question of dispossessing of its feminine attributes - its role as a mother and its essential differences vis-à-vis men - so that it becomes truly productive.  Beyond the ideology of gender at work in this report, Maria Noichl and the MEPs who voted for this text trample on the principle of subsidiarity enshrined in the European treaties, since they urge the Commission in particular to push states to recognise the LDC in national law, even though Article 4, paragraph 2, of the FUE Treaty does not mention family policy or , nor health policies as part of the Union's competence. The Noichl report is therefore an attack on the dignity of women and the dignity of nations.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE), in writing. – I believe that for the European Parliament it must be a permanent concern and a goal of full equality at all levels of men and women. We must develop and implement a strategy that completes this effort for all EU member countries. Violations of women's rights, whether at work or state level, must be eliminated and the EU must identify these violations and call on member countries to comply with strict compliance.

name: Damian DRĂGHICI
text: in writing. – Gender equality is a fundamental value, and the EU must take on the task of integrating gender equality into all its activities and reducing occupational inequalities. For all the efforts made so far, the differences between the Roma population and the majority society in education, health, employment remain great and the situation of Roma women in the Union is even worse as a result of multiple discrimination. The European Commission must take responsibility for drafting and adopting a new, separate strategy for the equality of women's rights in Europe, which creates equal opportunities, with the aim of ending all forms of discrimination faced by women in the labour market, in terms of wages, pensions, decision-making, the reconciliation of private and professional life, but also all forms of violence against women. I believe that cooperation between Member States, women's rights organisations and social partners should be promoted in order to provide adequate funding to national anti-discrimination bodies.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: writing – 2015 is a very important year for assessing the progress made by the European Union in the field of gender equality. In fact, despite various initiatives, there is still an unequal approach and conditions of employment due to gender discrimination. Ensuring gender equality in all areas of life is progressing very slowly. Women's uneasy position on the labour market is most pronounced in unjustified pay gaps, non-standard contracts, but also in generally limited employment opportunities and opportunities. It is for this very reason that we need to focus in the coming years on adopting very effective and precisely targeted legislation that will eliminate all forms of discrimination against women, but also against men. The citizens of the Member States of the European Union do not deserve to make endless excuses for the economic and financial crisis and the consolidation of the budget. Achieving gender equality is also of great importance for the economy and economy and is important for sustainable and inclusive growth. In future, we must focus on taking such measures and adopting legislation that actively combats violence against women, creates a level playing field for both men and women in the labour market, enables women to hold more leadership and management positions in the business sector and more involve women in decision-making processes.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: in writing. – The current strategy is coming to an end and the Commission needs to present a new strategy as soon as possible because equality between women and men continues to be an unreachable challenge in the EU, progress is slow and we need to continue to insist on key issues such as the fight against gender-based violence, which is the most widespread human rights violation in the world and which affects all strata of society; the incorporation of women into the equal labour market, without discrimination of any kind; the wage gap, which remains stable at an average of 16.4% in the EU and has even increased in some countries such as Spain; sexual and reproductive health rights, including the right to abortion under safe legal and health conditions; the difficult reconciliation of family and work life, which prevents many women from working full-time and even forces them to leave the labour market; the situation of vulnerable groups of women such as disabled women, immigrants, the elderly, Gypsies, etc.; or the poor representation of women in political and economic decision-making.

name: Enrico GASBARRA
text: in writing. – The path to gender equality is a priority that Europe cannot afford to underestimate: the path to full equality and equality of rights and opportunities between women and men is still going too slowly and I expect a breakthrough from this European legislature. Combating social discrimination, fighting abuse and violence harshly, overcoming gender pay and opportunity gaps, encouraging new and more inclusive labour policies are just some of the immediate actions that Europe must focus on in order to propose a higher level of protection and rights. There can be no equality unless we decide to invest in education for respect and the recognition of equal dignity of all the resources that our society has, regardless of gender, religion, culture and the sexual choices of the individual. Capitalising on human value and restoring freedom, consideration and respect for those who do not always have freedom today: I am convinced that this objective can lead to the achievement of Europe's main growth strategies.

name: Anneli JÄÄTTEENMÄKI
text: Written. – Women's fundamental rights are human rights. This sounds obvious to many citizens, but unfortunately it is not even for us in Europe. That is why women's fundamental rights need to be underlined. Women and men continue to play an unequal role in the world of work. The average pay gap between women and men is 16.4%. In pensions, the difference is even greater, 39%. This is due to the division of jobs into men's and women's jobs, but there is also much to be done in reconciling work and family life. That is why I am in favour of reforming the Maternity Leave Directive. I hope that the Council will have the political will and the Commission will have the courage to bring this important directive to a conclusion.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. This 'strategy' consists of a catch-all that mixes gender theory, interference in the affairs of Member States, interference in the lives of homes, but, let us stress, some good ideas deserve support. It is commendable and necessary to protect women by combating harassment, forced prostitution and the unfair dismissal of pregnant women. It is honourable and more than necessary to protect young girls from genital mutilation, early and forced marriage, and all the abuse they suffer.  But the "strategy" does not stop there and encourages, in a jumbled, immigration and communitarianism, gender theory and the implementation of quotas. Overcoming its remit, the Commission encourages the Union to take the place of the Member States to make decisions, and goes so far as to interfere in our homes by asking men to participate more in domestic work. When do checks to see who does the housework and ironing?  What is needed to resolve the excesses is to return to the values that were ours: to put in place the notions of respect, merit and work, and above all to insist on freedom of choice.

name: Bart STAES
text: Written. – This initiative report deserves all the support. It provides the Commission with input for the EU strategy between women and men after 2015. I regret that the Christian Democrats have put forward an alternative resolution that is much weaker. She does not mention sexual and reproductive health rights, LGBTIQ+ rights (lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender, intersex, and questioning) or multiple discrimination. She is weak on the references to violence against women. It gives weak institutional recommendations.  Even in my own constituency, there is still no equality between men and women. This was recently demonstrated by the Equal Pay Day campaign by She-kant and the Institute for The Equality of Women and Men. The pay gap has narrowed slightly, but on average a woman earned 9% less per hour than a man in 2012.  Belgium is also not doing the best thing in terms of partner violence. In 2013, for example, 162 people were killed by partner violence and 39,746 reported to the police. The number of Belgians who were victims of domestic violence increased to almost 1 in 20. Incredibly shocking figures! It is time for this to be done at European level, but also in the Member States.  Respect is the basis of any relationship, regardless of gender, migration or socioeconomic background.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: The next item is the one-minute speeches on important political issues.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: Madam President, there is no need to stress here the challenge of unemployment, especially that of young people. We cannot tolerate the sacrifice of a generation in this way: more than five million young people are unemployed, more than 50% in some states. That is not acceptable. The "youth" guarantee is being put in place and additional resources have been freed up. It is important, but we have to continue the effort. Too many young people leave the school system without qualifications. Too many jobs cannot find a candidate because of a lack of qualifications and adequate training. All actors today recognize the need to develop alternating teaching and learning. Where these systems are put in place, it works. So let's learn from it and put in place an ambitious system of alternating training at European level. We need to relaunch social dialogue. Social actors do the same kind of analysis. The Commission can propose to the social partners to negotiate an agreement to meet this important challenge.

name: Anneliese DODDS
text: – Madam President, the second reading of an EU Referendum Bill will take place tomorrow in the British House of Commons. It looks as though the referendum will occur next year. Until then, David Cameron has said he will focus on trying to renegotiate Britain’s relationship with the EU. Labour MEPs have been fighting for many years to reform Europe. We have argued that the EU budget must focus more on promoting jobs and growth; that national parliaments should engage more with EU policymaking; and that where EU regulations are not working, they must be changed. But Cameron is taking Britain’s name in vain in these negotiations. His plans include abandoning the tightening-up of the Posted Workers Directive, making wage—undercutting worse, not better. He is also trying to dilute forms of protection in the Working Time and Agency Workers Directives and the Social Chapter. Yes, we need EU reform, but we need reform that works for employees, for pensioners, for the unemployed and for the vast majority of businesses, which accept the need for a minimum floor of protections at work.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: – Thank you, Madam President, the latest proposal from the European Commission to distribute illegal migrants to other Member States of the European Union is outrageous and directly affects and threatens Bulgaria's interests.  Last year Bulgaria accepted and granted status to 2.5 times more illegal migrants than Italy, and 2.7 times more than Greece, and the current new proposal to redistribtributed new migrants is unfair, in solidarity and contrary to the national interest. The state cannot afford to accept more illegal migrants.  In this case, the Treaty on European Union, Article 73, should also be triggered and this burden should be borne jointly and severally between Member States, because the opposite means injustice and means a vicious and non-solidarity-based solution to this issue. I urge the European Commission to reconsider its proposal and declare Bulgaria a state of emergency.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: – Madam President, today Wolfgang Münchau said it clearly: Greece needs to survive and eventually to prosper within the eurozone. Anything less than that is surely not acceptable to the Greek people. With a 25% drop in income and debt piling up on all sides, the Greeks know that more of the same simply will not work. If the rest of the eurozone does not see what is in front of their noses, then they are just plain stubborn, they are happy to play with fire or they simply do not care. This week many of us will speak of the geopolitical importance of a trade deal with the US, and we are right to do so. Yet at so many different levels we have a geopolitical crisis sliding towards disaster within the eurozone. Whether your cold logic tells you that we must preserve an intact eurozone, or whether your social conscience cannot live with the impact of the economic crisis on Greek citizens, does not matter, because this has gone way beyond politics. European politicians have to stop playing to the gallery, whether in Brussels, Strasbourg, Athens or Berlin. If we do not fix it – and properly this time – we are sowing the seeds of our own destruction.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: – Mr President, in Ireland almost four family homes a day are now being lost to banks. This is not happening by accident: it is a result of Irish government policy that has been pursued with the approval and the instigation of the European institutions. It is a policy that resulted in 42% of the cost of Europe’s banking crisis been burdened on the Irish people, and now Irish families are paying the price with their homes. It is a policy that saw Irish and European banks bailed out and preferential interest rates offered to those of extreme wealth, while those who played no hand, and had no part, in the creation of the crisis are now forced to become homeless. The Irish people had a debt of EUR 64 billion foisted on our backs, and we are now witnessing our friends, our families and our neighbours paying again with their homes. This is not a recovery, not by any objective standards. There should – and must – be a change in direction by the Irish Government and at EU level to place the burden of debt on those who actually championed the cause of our crisis.

name: João FERREIRA
text: – Mr President, in the European Union and the euro area, the crisis does not yet have an end in sight. The prospect is that it can drag on for a long time, even if there are those who talk about secular stagnation.  Persistently high and structural unemployment and poverty, growing inequalities, it is against this background that we see new and repeated attempts at political blackmail and financial asphyxiation to double the will of the Greek people, but not only of the Greeks, generally all who dare rise up against exploitation, unemployment and hunger, and fight for democracy and national sovereignty , progress and social justice.  But what Merkel, Hollande, Juncker, Draghi and Lagarde believe to be a show of strength is nothing but a sign of their immense weakness. It is increasingly clear in the eyes of the peoples the radical incompatibility between the rules of economic and monetary union and any sovereign development project capable of breaking with the setback of civilizational dimension in which several peoples have been ensnared.  The option is clear: the breakor the rewind.

name: Josep-Maria TERRICABRAS
text: – Mr President, I would like to denounce a very serious development which has happened recently: last week, Interpol organized an important meeting of the police and intelligence services of 37 countries on counter-terrorism and international jihadism in Barcelona. Spanish Interior Minister Jorge Fernández Díaz has managed to get Interpol not to invite the Catalan police, who have provided important services in the deactivation of jihadist cells. The Catalan police have not been invited to Barcelona; the rest of the world, yes. It is grotesque and incomprehensible that the Spanish minister's anti-national catalan obsession prevails over his obligation to protect citizens, and it is also incomprehensible that Interpol should agree to the minister's raving and is not interested in knowing in Barcelona what the Catalan police are doing. My complaint and my complaint go against Minister Fernández Díaz and Against Interpol. They'll go and go.

name: Louise BOURS
text: – Mr President, during the recent UK general election, Mr Cameron said that scrapping the tampon tax would be quite difficult. It is not quite difficult, it is nigh on impossible. The UK is subject to EU rules on VAT which force us to impose a 5% tax on these and many other products. There is nothing anyone can do about it because only the unelected and unaccountable EU Commission can propose or begin to amend legislation. So it does not matter how you vote in elections, you cannot vote for anybody that can actually initiate change to EU law. The only way we are going to get rid of this ridiculous tax is for politicians to start listening to the electorate, decide they will do what is best for their voters, not the project, and leave the EU. Once we leave the EU we can act swiftly, follow in Canada’s footsteps and get rid of this archaic tax on feminine hygiene products.

name: Mario BORGHEZIO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, for some months now in Rome, the judicial authority has been carrying out an investigation called 'Mafia Capitale'. Think of it, the European capital city, where the Treaties of Rome were signed, is today the subject of an investigation called "Mafia Capitale", with contracts, a mafia dome, contracts on contracts, bribes, a system of power rooted in all the parties that dominate the politics of the capital of Italy, Rome.  I ask that the European Parliament make its voice heard, the President should ask the Italian Government why the municipality of Rome has not yet been dissolved for the Mafia. We must free the Roman citizens, who are overwhelmingly honest working people, from the occupation of this mafia business dome of the various parties, which even speculated through mafia-infected cooperatives on contributions for migrants and nomads: a disgrace! No more Mafia Capitale!

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: – As Europeans, we are well aware of the consequences of spreading hate propaganda. Maybe we thought something like this couldn't happen again. However, Russian state television recently described the inhabitants of Czechoslovakia, who faced a Soviet invasion in 1968, as fascists. They also call the people of Ukraine, who are fighting for the territorial integrity of their homeland. I call on you, my colleagues in the European Parliament, as well as all the Member States of the European Union, to stand in solidarity and act together against such lies and manipulations. We can't know who's going to be their target next time. Sticking and dehumanising an adversary is always the first step towards justifying aggression and violence. I believe that it is the common European approach that is the best answer against the spread of lies, propaganda and aggression. Thank you in advance for your support.

name: Richard CORBETT
text: – Mr President, my colleague Anneliese Dodds has already spoken eloquently of what Mr Cameron is trying to do at the moment, as he scuttles around Europe placing demands for so-called reform on the table, trying to find a route between the trivial and the impossible. However, the right wing of his party is trying to push him into making demands that are not in the British national interest, nor in the European interest, but are highly partisan Conservative policies that they wish him to impose on the rest of Europe. He will only succeed, if he goes down that route, by two rounds of blackmail. In round one he says to other EU countries, ‘Accept these changes or we are off, and I really mean it’; and then in round two, if he gets those changes, he says to the British people, ‘You have a choice between what I have negotiated or leaving Europe’. It is Cameron’s Europe or no Europe, and at that point he will tell the British people to stay in and accept his terms. I do hope that there are still some pro-European Conservatives who dare raise their head above the parapet and argue against him in their own party to make sure that this does not happen.

name: Zbigniew KUŹMIUK
text: – I would like to draw the European Commission's attention to the very difficult situation of farmers – milk producers – in my country, Poland. As a result of the Russian embargo, as well as the lifting of milk production limits, the prices of this raw material have already fallen by about 20%. At the same time, farmers will be fined for exceeding production limits for the second year in a row. These penalties will amount to around EUR 150 million and will be collected from payments to farmers for the current supply of milk by September this year, while prices for the raw material delivered to the collection points have plummeted. In this situation, after the payment of penalties, the remaining part of the income derived from the sale of milk is certainly not sufficient to cover the costs of production, and that means losses and inability to regulate the remaining obligations of dairy farms, including credit obligations. I therefore ask the Commission once again to take an interest in the situation of dairy farms in Poland and to prepare solutions to support this production throughout the Union at this very difficult time for milk producers.

name: Lynn BOYLAN
text: – Mr President, Ireland has been rocked by another financial scandal that the European Parliament should be made aware of. Our Taoiseach, Enda Kenny, was missing in action, while one man, media mogul Denis O’Brien, tried to censor coverage of the scandal. He sought to prevent disclosure of a deal between himself and the state-owned IBRC through which he acquired a company at a discount of EUR 190 million at the taxpayers’ expense. While Denis O’Brien was slapping gagging orders on our national broadcaster and threatening to sue parliamentarians for using Dáil privilege, Enda Kenny was nowhere to be found. This is the same Enda Kenny who in Paris was quick to defend freedom of the press. At the same time, the Finance Minister, Michael Noonan, was absolving the government of any involvement in the whole saga. This is the same Michael Noonan who ruled out support for any debt deal for Greece, but who declared debt write-downs to be normal when it comes to selling assets to powerful friends. So, once again, we have the Irish taxpayers picking up the tab for corporate greed.

name: Ernest MARAGALL
text: – Mr President, from Turkey we are given hope this Sunday; the day after tomorrow, we must correspond with the same stillness.  But today I wanted to talk to you about Palestine. I've been there four intense days, listening to each other's voices, and understanding, playing, trying to understand what's going on. The conclusion is clear: Europe is absent – or present to a minimum and secondary degree – while Israel strongly and unsuemoniously implements a strategy of consummate facts that makes any peaceful solution impossible, let alone the theoretically accepted hypothesis of one territory and two States.  We are installed in an obscene normality that Europe cannot accept or accept, maintaining the passive silence that characterises us.
