A silence purportedly compensated by the frequent resolutions that this Parliament adopts, but which in fact serve to confirm the absolute impunity of the current Israeli government policy. It is in Europe's hands to avoid it.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: – Mr President, in my constituency, the North-East of England, we have a proud sporting heritage. Today I would like to mention the sport of boxing. Last year two North-East boxers faced each other for a world title for the first time, and today the United Kingdom has five world champions at different weights. For young people boxing provides opportunities. A young disadvantaged person who would otherwise find themselves tempted by crime, drugs and violence can find a safe refuge where they can learn about self-discipline, respect and how to properly deal with life’s problems. Research shows that boxing is actually far less dangerous than many other contact sports. It is a safe and rewarding activity that is brilliant for physical fitness and has taken many young people to the Olympics and beyond. So I would just like to pay tribute to the many trainers who work very hard with young people in my constituency.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: June 4th was the 95th anniversary of the signing of the Trianon Peace Treaty. For us Hungarians, this is a day of mourning. At the end of World War I, the unjust dictation of the victors brutally dismembered my country, Hungary, which was not responsible for the war, by taking away two-thirds of our territory and driving three and a half million Hungarians under the rule of foreign states. We Hungarians will never accept this, we will never accept it.  The right of self-determination is granted to all peoples, but hungarians are still denied it, even though over the last three decades many European peoples have been able to live with it, form an independent state, unite with the motherland or achieve territorial autonomy. Millions of Hungarians, who are native national communities, live in disenfranchise in their homelands. It is a shame that the European Union tolerates this.  In order to preserve European security, we also demand the revision of the infamous Trianon diktat and the right of self-determination for Hungarians living in Transylvania, the Highlands, the Southland and Transcarpathia! No, no, never! Lose Trianon!

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank you for your support. I would like to draw attention to a very important ecological and social catastrophe, which threatens several EU member states due to the neglected state of the mine settlement of Aknaszlatina near the Ukrainian-Hungarian-Romanian border and the continuous contamination of the Tisza with concentrated salt solution.  Mineslatina was created above europe's most extensive salt field. Since the 1990s, the technical condition of salt mines has deteriorated, and regular water shortages and lack of money have put the effectiveness of water intrection protection of salt mines at great risk. Mining collapses have become regular, with huge craters forming near salt mines, directly endangering the inhabitants and infrastructure of the settlement. Although the salt mines have ceased to operate, the size of the collapses is now more than three million cubic meters. However, due to the current situation, the Ukrainian Government is unable to pay attention to this and money has ceased to be funded. The authorities saw the solution in the evacuation of the population, forty-five kilometers from the current salt mine. The public does not accept this evacuation, so this is the last moment to help prevent this ecological and social catastrophe. Thank you!

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the Istat 2015 annual report also presents Italy at two speeds in health care. I fail to say, in the North it works and in the South it is in difficulty. In the south we are at the lowest per capita expenditure, only EUR 1 700 in Campania, while in other areas of the country it exceeds EUR 2 000 per capita.  This aspect forms a vicious spiral, which combined with the statistical inverse that sees the incidence of many diseases higher in the South, makes the principle of the quality of life evanescent and even utopian. An inclusive and balanced level of care that is ultimately within the reach of the citizen is a pipe light in the southern regions. The sleep of the reason for uninitiated planning has generated the monsters of structural collapse and deaths incomparably higher than the national average, for both men and women, for all the main causes of death.  I hope that the awareness will return that every day of waiting is a day of lack of help for those who have the right to receive it. The Commission, with the Italian national and regional authorities, stimulates the most appropriate lines of intervention to guarantee the universality of care through a health service without social and territorial disparities.

name: Anna FOTYGA
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by In response to the ban on entry to Russia imposed m.in. on a group of European parliamentarians, The President of parliament Martin Schulz applied diplomatic sanctions and restrictions on interparamentary contacts. These are the right and right decisions. Although I am on the Russian blacklist, I believe that parliamentary retort was taken far too late. The right moment was the illegal annexation of Crimea, or the subsequent time when the self-proclaimed authorities broke the rights of minorities living there for centuries, or when the Minsk agreements, after all, were violated. I believe that such sanctions would allow us to avoid controversial discussions with Mr Puszków in the AFET committee or equally controversial meetings during meetings of the EU-Russia delegation.

name: Yana TOOM
text: – Mr President, I am deeply concerned about practices in relation to the application of the Schengen rules by the Baltic States. During the last seven months, a dozen Russian scholars, experts and people from the art world have been denied entry to, or expelled from, the Baltic States. Among them, for instance, was Valery Tishkov, a member of the Russian Academy of Sciences. His case is very curious. While in Russia, he has previously been harassed for his political and academic views. Baltic intolerance towards criticism by experts and scholars sends a very bad signal to the Kremlin. Bad practices on the part of the Baltic States may shed some light on the reasons behind the so-called Russian blacklist. National authorities are given wide discretion to decide on entry to their territory and to the territory of the Schengen zone. I believe, however, that we need more coherent supranational control over the application of the Schengen rules. Such application should not compromise the democratic image of the Union.

name: Giulia MOI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the echo of the investigation that is upsetting Rome will also have reached the heart of Europe: for everyone it is Mafia Capitale. For us in the Five Star Movement, it is the tip of an iceberg of mischie and exchanges of votes and bribes that we have been denouncing for a long time. The corruption of local politicians and the administrative apparatus is a ballast that is being loaded on to the shoulders of citizens and hindering the development of the whole country. My region, Sardinia, has unfortunately been a manger for decades, to which many, too many well-known draw with impunity without rules and bypassing the laws. They are un controls and usually have no punishment. I am speaking today so that all our colleagues do not allow themselves to be dazzled by the propaganda that our executive is setting in motion to obscure what is happening in Italy, but we are even aware of the disaster within which our governments are dragging us.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: Mr President, 20 NGOs have just slammed the door on the European Alcohol and Health Forum. They accuse the Commission of abandoning the European alcohol strategy, which was launched in 2006. Many MEPs want to revive this strategy. I don't agree with them. It is certainly important to combat alcoholism, particularly by developing a policy of prevention towards young people, but I believe that it is up to the States, not the Union, to do so. In accordance with the principle of subsidiarity, each State is in fact better able than the Union to find an adequate balance between the fight against alcoholism on the one hand and the protection of its wine traditions on the other. It is a matter of safeguarding its sovereignty. That is why I welcome the brussels Commission's decline and I hope it is only the first in a long series.

name: Elissavet VOZEMBERG-VRIONIDI
text: PPE). Mr President, in recent times there has been an uncontrolled increase in irregular migrants entering Greece from the northern Greek-Turkish maritime border, which is now 500% higher than last year, especially in the islands of the southeastern Aegean.  I have repeatedly called for the approval of specific funds for Greece to deal with the phenomenon, which the UNHCR has also pointed out, noting that these islands in particular do not have the adequate infrastructure to adequately care for these people.  Local authorities on the Greek islands are sounding the alarm to give Greece the necessary financial assistance and to implement quickly the European Commission's new programme for the relocation of 16,000 migrants to other European Union countries. I call on the Commission to speed up the implementation of emergency measures, in view of the tourist season, to relieve the affected areas.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: - Mr. President, since it was introduced, the Single European Emergency Number 112 has significantly improved the assistance system for the afflicted across Europe. But since then little attention has been paid to its promotion and promotion. The data suggests that three-quarters of European Union citizens are unaware that the number can save their lives, and 70% have heard nothing about it in the last year. There is also no progress in accurately determining the location of the afflicted, despite the development of technology. The emergency access expert group has not met since 2013. Also, the SMS service of contacting the number 112 roaming does not work, which is a significant problem for people with special needs. So, we urgently need better coordination and information to more effectively protect our citizens and make the job easier for those who selflessly help the afflicted. The Croatian Mountain Rescue Service, 800 volunteers who care about the safety of citizens 24 hours a day, certainly belongs here. This year, the European Parliament also recognised their work by awarding them the European Citizen Award, for which I congratulate them once again.

name: Marek JUREK
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab The European Commission is now pushing for the principle of forced and quota-based sending of migrants across Europe – in the name of solidarity – in violation of the findings of the European Council, but solidarity, which poles do not need to teach us, is first respect for someone else's rights. This is respect for common arrangements. Of course, solidarity is first of all respect for the rights that we should already respect. Polish farmers do not yet receive the same direct payments as farmers from the big Countries of the European Union , those countries that belonged to the Union when, at the time when we were associationd in the 1990s, our farmers were restricted in export opportunities, even though we opened our market without restrictions to western European exports. This injustice needs to be fixed as soon as possible.

name: Romana TOMC
text: – We recently obtained a Eurostat study that sought to outline the different dimensions of quality of life, our well-being. This means a standard of living or individual's access to goods and services. I was particularly drawn to the noting that higher education can mean a better future, a better quality of life and a higher standard. But is that really the case? Then why do we have a so-called lost generation? Why are there so many highly educated young people in the European Union without adequate employment? We have a number of strategies, reports, we are doing everything at European level to ensure young people have a decent future, but we simply do not get the results to the extent that we want them. Are we really doing everything right, and shouldn't there be something to change in this area?

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: – At its last plenary session in Strasbourg, the European Parliament addressed the so-called anti-foreigner and misleading national consultation launched by the Hungarian Government. This week we will even adopt a resolution on this here in Parliament.  Since then, however, the situation in Hungary has unfortunately deteriorated considerably, since this week the government used €1 million of public money to launch an anti-immigrant, xenophobic billboard campaign across the country. This provoked a huge outcry from Hungarians, and a real national movement was launched to cover at least the xenophobic parts of these posters. In response, the Hungarian police ordered the protection of these posters. Plainclothes detectives were assigned to the posters across the country and even ordered fingerprints to be recorded there. This type of police action is obviously exaggerated and disproportionate, and we must make this clear, as hungarian former police chiefs have done. We must condemn this kind of action here in the European Parliament.

name: Jaromír ŠTĚTINA
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the G7 meeting attempted to pretend European unity. Mrs Merkel did her best, but failed to make a significant shift in condemning Russian aggression in Ukraine. Sanctions will continue, this is a positive outcome of the summit. Today, however, it is quite clear that neither sanctions themselves nor any other Minsk agreements are enough. Any such indecision that we have seen in Bavaria is what Putin needs. I mean, ladies and gentlemen, Putin is mocking us. It also attacks the Donbas with heavy weapons, developing a hybrid war against Europe. Ukraine has bravely decided not to submit to Russia's power pressure and to move freely toward its future. How is it supposed to apply reforms to meet the requirements of the International Monetary Fund when it is in its own territory? We're playing for time, the conflict is tearing Ukraine down. There was no report from the summit that it was of the utmost importance to support Ukraine militarily by supplying arms and ammunition and to declare it openly. Kudos to Ukraine!

name: Emilian PAVEL
text: – Mr President, I want to raise the alarm about the situation in Romania today, which colleagues in the EPP are wrong to turn into a cause for political dispute at european level, as the opposition calls for the resignation of the Prime Minister, trying to reach government by undemocratic means and overturn a legitimate majority. What is this government doing right now? Relaunched the economy; we are now recording the highest economic growth at European level, at 4,3 %; steadily increased wages, pensions and doubled child benefit; reduced VAT on food products so that we have 12% discounts on food; reduced labour charges by generating more than 90 000 new jobs in the last year alone; completed a master transport plan; has greatly increased the absorption of European funds and is working on a wage law that will lead to an increase in low wages. What's he been up to? He blocked several mafias that were abusively exploiting forests, ting the energy market, stealing VAT, smuggling and smuggling. This good governance is at risk today because the LNP really wants to get into government before next year.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: – Mr President, excess alcohol contributes to about 25% of all road deaths in Europe – that is 6 500 deaths per year – and, according to research by the Commission, a large part of the problem involves high-risk offenders who offend regularly and exceed legal blood/alcohol levels by a large amount. Road deaths in Europe at present stand at 26 000 per year. That is down from 55 000, over the 14 years since 2001. A target has been set to reduce the figure to zero, and Commissioner Bulc is doing a lot in this area. The Commission is also currently reviewing which technologies should be included in new vehicles. I would like to promote – and to ensure that they include in their communications with Member States – alcohol interlocks. Interlocks are automatic control systems which are designed to prevent driving with excess alcohol by requiring the driver to blow into an in-car breathalyser before starting the ignition. This technology can be part of the armoury available to national judicial systems, and I would urge the Commission to ensure that the success of these devices is included in its armoury and shared with Member States.

name: Claudiu Ciprian TĂNĂSESCU
text: – Mr President, your colleagues at the EPP have misinformed you and that is why I have to make some clarifications about the situation in Romania. I bring to your attention the critical situation that the members of the Romanian opposition have triggered and support by a serious departure from European democratic practices, which is likely to affect regional political stability in Eastern Europe. , without being previously heard and without being given the chance to present his position. Then the NLP began to exert political and media pressure to determine the resignation of Prime Minister Victor Ponta with the stated aim of taking over the government now exercised by a legitimate government, supported by a legitimate parliamentary majority supported by a broad coalition. I draw attention to the point that the actions of the Liberals can not only lead to a serious political crisis, but involve justice in political decisions, thus disregarding both the national legislation in force and the generally valid European laws. ... (The President interrupted the speaker's speech.)

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: – Mr President, I regret that our parliament has not agreed to hear Victor Ponta as a matter of urgency. The Romanian prime minister is accused of corruption by DNA prosecutors and when the country's president asked him to resign he replied that this would be a coup. Today, when Mr Pittella's Socialists were defending him here in plenary, the Romanian Prime Minister threatened criminal investigations against opposition leaders and citizens who would dare to take to the streets to protest in the coming days. This is a serious authoritarian drift. A plagiarism specialist, Victor Ponta is now copying Viktor Yanukovych's anti-democratic behavior. If he were innocent, the Prime Minister would demand the lifting of his parliamentary immunity so that he could clarify the corruption allegations against him. Instead, he mobilized the state to avoid the rigors of the law. The Socialist prime minister in Bucharest must be stopped because he now aims to abolish an institution that deals with corruption investigations. "Go away!" they call out to citizens in Bucharest - I'm doing it here.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: – This item on the agenda has been closed.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: The next item is the brief presentation of the Alessia Maria MOSCA report on Intellectual Property Rights in Third Countries [2014/2206(INI)] (A8–0161/2015).

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, counterfeit products are harmful to consumers and are detrimental to the economy, to quality production and to research. That is why we believe it is crucial to have a strategy for the enhancement and protection of intellectual property rights that is at the same time able to be attentive to the possible impact on the accessibility of certain sensitive products such as medicines and that does not restrict individual rights. These are the principles on which we based the own-initiative reports on the strategy for the protection and strengthening of intellectual property rights in third countries, voted on in the Committee on International Trade on 14 April. The report responds to the Commission's communication of July 2014 which sought, for the first time, to propose new action in this area, following the failure of ACTA. Intellectual property rights have undergone extraordinary evolution over the last ten years, due to the impressive speed with which technological innovations have spread, even in emerging countries. For this reason, a strategy that wants to be effective must first take account of these developments and propose coherent actions. It is estimated that at present 39% of the total economic activity of the European Union and 26% of employment, i.e. 56 million jobs, are generated by companies that invest and make use of intellectual property rights.  In the report we are presenting today for Parliament's vote, we first of all welcome the approach taken by the Commission, especially since it takes into account in a balanced way divergent interests, those of intellectual property rights holders on the one hand and those of consumers on the other. In general, there is no legislation that works well unless the involvement of all the actors concerned is stimulated and guaranteed. All the more so, in this context, it is essential that all citizens, even in the smallest daily gestures, are aware and responsible, so that all forms of counterfeiting of physical goods and piracy of digital goods are eliminated. Counterfeit products are no longer just luxury goods, but also everyday products such as toys, medicines, cosmetics and food products, which therefore pose a risk to consumer health. That is also why we call on the Commission in its report to ensure that there is a constant commitment to the involvement, transparency, communication and coordination of all actions. Going into more detail, the main points of our report concern: the need to differentiate between physical counterfeiting of trademarks and patents and copyright infringements; the call for closer cooperation between regulators and customs; the establishment of a constructive dialogue involving the various stakeholders; the strengthening of the European Observatory on infringement of intellectual property rights with total management independence; the need to adapt the price of generic medicines to the situation in the individual countries where they are marketed in order to allow anyone access to the products; the need to emphasise that geographical indications are just as important as other types of intellectual property, inso far as they ensure product traceability for the benefit of consumers and safeguard the skills of producers; a greater presence of help-desks on intellectual property rights in developing countries.  In conclusion, in our opinion, the communication is an excellent first step, but it must necessarily be followed up. It is also crucial for the European Union to have a coherent internal regulatory framework in this area, which would ensure not only greater effectiveness, but also greater negotiating strength, both in bilateral relations and in multilateral discussions.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: – Mr President, considering the significant changes that have taken place in the area of IPR over the past decade, I believe that protection and enforcement of intellectual property rights is indeed a very important issue to tackle in order to fight the threat that infringement poses to EU creative industries, jobs and growth. I welcome this initiative and I appreciate the fact that the approach taken in ACTA, which mixed hard goods with internet supervision, was overcome. I am in favour of the Commission proposal to review the strategy for the protection and enforcement of IPR in third countries. This approach is valued by the different stakeholders and underlines that any initiative concerning external IPR enforcement should carefully reflect the internal EU development of IP rules.  Finally, I would like to welcome the inclusion by our group of the safeguarding of the flow of generic medicines, which strikes the right balance between the production of generic medicines and the protection of pharmaceutical research.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Mr President, competitiveness in the European Union must be based not on lower wages, but on innovation and the knowledge economy . Intellectual Property Rights Intensive Industries generate 39% of total economic activity in the European Union, worth EUR 4.7 trillion per year, and employ 26% of the total workforce, i.e. 56 million workers.  A framework for the legal protection of intellectual property rights is therefore needed, not only in the European Union but also in third countries. At the same time, the abuse of rights by holders of intellectual property rights must be overturned and the creation of monopolistic situations of exploitation and profiteering must be reversed.  In particular, with regard to pharmaceutical companies, which, by abusing their dominant position, have turned the marketing of medicines into an obscene over-profit-accumulation operation at the expense of third countries, the prices of medicines must be accessible to the poor peoples of Europe and third countries, because health is a public good and not a commodity.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: "Mr. President, there is no doubt that globalization has done a lot of good on our planet. There is no reason not to support global trade, the World Trade Organization and all that this trade of good brings.  However, we must start from the fact that globalization has brought a huge number of problems. One of these problems is certainly large counterfeits and all that can be additionally purchased by logic and distribution through e-commerce. So, in this particular case when we talk about third countries, I think we definitely have to help those countries that want to protect intellectual property because it protects ourselves because counterfeits are not only a question of brands of various handbags or some other sympathetic things, but e.g. a drug problem. So it's about our health and in that context I think the Commission needs to be supported.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: – Mr President, we have heard the report, and now Parliament has just five minutes to debate it before the Commission sums up. So if you are watching this at home, do not hard-boil an egg, you will miss the whole debate! I have read this 14-page report, and there are two words that I just cannot seem to find anywhere in it: small business. The big problem with intellectual property rights is ensuring that big business cannot submit mountains and mountains of patents on every conceivable issue and then sue any small business which introduces something which happens to look a little bit like one of those patents. Particularly in a digital age, I believe this point must not be forgotten.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, intellectual property rights develop along the historical path of constitutional charters, are linked to the universality of rights and are the basis with equal dignity of others, of the development of European and international civilisation.  Being able to preserve the originality of one's creative moment coincides with the creation of the work itself and with its translation into an asset of life, abstract and concrete, and is an achievement of the Western world. This need is even more evident today that scientific, literary and artistic production are not separated from innovation and condition competitiveness, employment and cultural diversity.  Consumer health and safety are also closely linked and represent the ultimate goal of scientific thought, which must develop according to human centrality. For example, the authenticity of medicines and food products is constantly under attack from the black economy and organised crime, and it is not just a problem of 'made in Europe'. I agree with the report and hope for a truly effective Eu ropean Union action plan, which will, as soon as possible, renew the legal framework of reference that no longer meets the modern need for protection and will also include third countries.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: – Thank you, Mr President, intellectual property has never been as crucial as it has been in recent years, not only in terms of innovation and technological progress, but also for the overall increase in digital awareness among consumers.  However, there are structural obstacles in the mechanisms for the implementation and enforcement of intellectual property regimes. Member States face different challenges as a result of a variety of factors, especially in countries with weak intellectual property regimes that have fallen victim to illicit trade in goods and services due to a lack of means to combat the spread of infringements.  In the European Union, we must keep in mind that a strong legal framework for intellectual property is very important. In order to function properly, it needs a strong and coherent toolbox in each Member State.  My country is among the most affected countries. Proximity to large eastern markets is a prerequisite for a large influx of counterfeit goods. According to the analyses, we must actively try to support intellectual property mechanisms through targeted coordinated supervisory projects and as a basis for good practice.

name: Tiziana BEGHIN
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, protecting intellectual property is certainly very important, but I believe that it is equally important to know exactly which intellectual property we are referring to. In our opinion, this report is to some degree acceptable, but we believe that it also contains some worrying elements.  The idea that it is necessary to impose our standards of protection of intellectual property on third countries may seem correct and partly correct, but if we do so in order to give the green light to European companies to relocate and produce in those countries, taking jobs away from Europe, which is already in crisis, we are certainly not doing the citizens a favour. Furthermore, the issue of copyright on the Internet is very thorny, it is clear that I do not want in any way to encourage piracy, but I cannot accept new mega upload cases either, such as when a site was closed from the office because it hosted, also but not limited to, some pirated files. I would also have liked to see a somewhat stronger stance on the issue of access to medicines. We must ensure that intellectual property rights are not a shield behind which the large multinationals hide their great interests. And this resolution seems to me to have wasted a little bit of an opportunity in this case.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank the rapporteur, Ms Mosca, and the Committee on International Trade for their valuable work on this report. The report underlines the high importance of protecting and enforcing intellectual property rights around the globe for our stakeholders. It also stresses the need for the Commission to not only continue but also go beyond the efforts it has been making in this regard. The Commission shares this vision. The Commission welcomes the appreciation shown for the approach that the strategy for the protection and enforcement of intellectual property rights in third countries takes in aiming to achieve a balance between divergent interests. It is certainly true that the debate about achieving a fair balance between right-holders’ interests and end-users’ interests is extremely complex, with economic interests on all sides. It is a concern to us all to see infringements of intellectual property rights (IPR) multiplying in recent years and taking away European knowledge and jobs. The Commission certainly welcomes the report’s call for further work to tackle this problem. Indeed there are many points expressed in the report that the Commission fully agrees with, such as, for example, the need for the following: wider informed stakeholder involvement in the debate on IPR; more consumer awareness about the consequences of infringements; and improved coherence between IPR protection and enforcement and other policies. It is also important to reaffirm that the relationship between IPR and universal access to affordable medicines is indeed complex and multi-faceted, a point which is often lost. Moreover, we must continue to ensure that appropriate attention is given to chapters on IPR in our free trade agreements. We also agree with the rapporteur that better, appropriately-harmonised, internal IPR-related EU policies could be helpful in the effort to improve the standard of protection and enforcement of IPR globally. Further assistance should be considered for developing countries wishing to improve their IPR systems. The Commission will be taking careful note of the recommendations made in the report during the implementation of the strategy for the protection and enforcement of intellectual property rights in third countries. We look forward to continuing to work with Parliament, and all of its stakeholders, in this exercise. Rest assured, furthermore, that I will pass all your comments made tonight to my colleague Cecilia Malmström, who is the Commissioner in charge of this file.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: The debate has been closed. The vote will take place on Tuesday, 9 June 2015. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. The report calls for a rigorous extension of intellectual property rights standards in third countries, and even calls for conditionality in this area to establish economic relations with those countries, without regard to the specific needs of developing countries, where intellectual property rights often undermine their industrial and development policies. In addition, the report addresses the problem of access to medicines from the perspective of large pharmaceutical companies turning their backs on people's right to access medicines. The report responds blindly to past experiences such as Ebola in West Africa or hepatitis C in Spain. There is evidence that research into new medicines is often guided not by public health demands, but by the economic benefit of pharmaceutical companies. Current incentives for patent research fail to raise enough for the development of new drugs that are really needed. It is time for the EU to take the lead in exploring new strategies in biomedical innovation that promote both affordable access to R&D outcomes and knowledge creation as public goods.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: The next item is the brief presentation of the Pavel SVOBODA report on Intellectual Property Rights: an EU action plan (2014/2151(INI)) (A8–0169/2015).

name: Pavel SVOBODA
text: Rapporteur. – Let me briefly present, on behalf of the Committee on Legal Affairs, a report on the road to a renewed consensus on the enforcement of intellectual property rights: the EU Action Plan. As I have said several times, I am particularly glad that the Committee on Legal Affairs as a whole has accepted my approach, which was to focus on the report on the Commission's action plan and not to engage in other related topics. I think there is a general consensus that intellectual property rights make a significant contribution to the economic growth of the European Union and its cultural diversity. For this reason, we therefore welcome the Commission's efforts to focus on improving tools for the enforcement of intellectual property rights.  I welcome the Commission's efforts to come up with instruments based on an understanding of the state of play in this area, based on verified facts and based on the consensus of all stakeholders. I believe that it is this consensus, this understanding of the widest possible range of stakeholders, that can ultimately contribute most to an effective system of enforcement of intellectual property rights. For this reason too, I believe that a precisely targeted information campaign can be both a means and an objective of an action plan. I think it does not hurt to mention how important the issue of fundamental rights can play. I certainly do not suspect the Commission of not respecting these principles, I just think that, from the point of view of public acceptance, the exclusion of any doubts in this area is essential and we should therefore treat the issue of fundamental rights with the utmost care.  Personally, I would like to support the Commission's follow the money approach. I think there is a general consensus that we want to put our efforts towards those who harm intellectual property rights holders in an organised way for profit, not for individual users. Personally, I would also like to support the Commission's proposals to help SMEs. I do not see these steps as examples of 'special treatment' precisely in the area of the enforcement of intellectual property rights, but only as one of a number of measures in the various areas in which we are interested in improving the position of SMEs.  I believe that an effective system for the enforcement of intellectual property rights is indeed essential for the future prosperity of the European Union, and I hope that the European Commission will make a major contribution to this. I believe that the enforcement of the Action Plan must be pursued without a hurry, a flexible response to a rapidly changing environment, concentrating only on effective and justified steps that will actually affect the better position of rightholders, because that is the purpose of all these measures, to strengthen the position of rightholders.  I therefore hope that the Commission will be able to present the first results of its work and its actions mentioned in the Action Plan by July 2016 at the latest.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Mr President, the protection of intellectual property rights is a driving force for employment and growth in the European Union. At the same time, it is vital for the smooth functioning of the internal market. In this context, the protection of intellectual property rights should include the adoption of an approach consisting of monitoring the money line in order to hit infringements of intellectual property rights who traffic counterfeit pirated products over the Internet.  This has resulted in a loss of revenue for small and medium-sized enterprises and national economies. On the other hand, there must be a fair balance of interests between the holders of these rights and end-users. Finally, at a time of economic crisis which is affecting the financing of culture as a result of cuts imposed by the Mercel fiscal adjustment, there should be greater support for culture on the part of the European Union.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Mr. President, I want to emphasize two facts. One is that creativity and innovation are a guarantee of quality economic growth and a guarantee of our future. No innovation, no research, no creativity, no growth, but innovation, research and creativity are looking for intellectual property protection right now.  Also, the second fact: it is SMEs that are the economic cornerstone of the European economy and bringing together these two facts, the desire for creativity precisely in these medium and small enterprises, is something I support and therefore support the Commission's position on the creation of an expert group on intellectual property protection. I also support the action plan that goes towards the protection of intellectual property, because all this together will allow us to have creativity, i.e. creativity. protected creativity comes to the forefront.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: – Mr President, it is important to defend and understand intellectual property rights as an issue that we have to see, in our view, especially with the interests of authors and creators and not especially in the interests of intermediary companies, who profit from what they consider to be only a commodity within the framework of the internal market, which naturally favours the largest companies and the economically stronger countries.  But there is one issue that we need to highlight and that seems important to us. For the knowledge and cultural value they produce, all those who produce knowledge and cultural and artistic value must have access to a professional status that dignifies them, not being held hostage to the sale of the piece of their work. And it is up to the States that it is up to the states to ensure this dignification. Unfortunately, the exact opposite has happened.  On the other hand, all people have the right to cultural enjoyment, to knowledge, and the essential remuneration of authors and creators should not fall on them, it would be fairer, yes, to fall on the intermediaries who profit from this work.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: – Mr President, by my count there are now just five MEPs out of 750 left in the Chamber for the second debate on intellectual property rights this evening. I speak to further my previous point about remembering the interests of small business. Brussels has more lobbyists than Washington DC. We have more than 30 000 lobbyists. To put that in context, that is over 40 lobbyists for every one MEP. No wonder constituents are complaining to me about big business lobbying, albeit on the issue of the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership. They are right to do so. I thank the rapporteur for mentioning the interests of small businesses. Particularly in fields like software development, small business can be squashed by the legal teams of big business. The people I want to be lobbied by are not the large corporations. I want to be lobbied by my constituents.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank the House for all the points that have been made and for your work, led by Mr Svoboda, on this report. The European Parliament has made an important contribution to what must be a joint effort to promote and protect creativity and innovation in the EU. Along with its action in renovating the legislative framework in some key areas of intellectual property rights (IPR), the Commission has decided to take targeted action to enforce these rights in the internal market. We are faced with a very difficult and complex reality: commercial-scale IPR-infringing activities have become more frequent and therefore very harmful to the EU economy, and in particular to the individuals and companies who are supposed to benefit from these rights. Commercial-scale IPR-infringing activities are a deterrent to investment in innovation and creativity. They result directly in lost revenue to legitimate businesses, lost tax revenue, lost jobs and high enforcement costs. Therefore, it is of the utmost importance to implement adequate measures against activities of this type. The Action Plan adopted by the Commission in July 2014 comprises various non-legislative measures, all of which aim to boost and secure European businesses’ innovation and creativity in order to preserve their competitiveness in trade at global level. As is reflected in Mr Svoboda’s report, the Commission’s efforts in the area of IPR enforcement should remain focused on several important points, such as the protection of consumers against harmful counterfeit goods; stronger support for SMEs; clarifying the role of intermediaries, especially in the digital environment; promoting the implementation of due diligence mechanisms in global supply chains, and so on. Under the leadership of Vice-President Ansip and Commissioner Bieńkowska, we are now moving forward and have been working directly with national authorities and industry stakeholders on each of these issues. Parliament’s support will be crucial throughout the process. But I also want to bring your attention to the fact that, despite the good faith of various voluntary initiatives envisaged in the 2014 Action Plan, the enforcement of IPR may also require legislative change. The recently-presented Digital Single Market Strategy calls for smarter enforcement for copyright. This does not mean, of course, that less importance should be given to other intellectual property rights, the infringement of which is very harmful to the EU economy. In view of that, over the coming months, the Commission will carry out an evaluation of the overall functioning of the current legal framework for IPR enforcement. If the evaluation shows a need for amendment, this will be an important focus of the Commission’s work in the future. To conclude, I would like to thank Parliament once again for its positive consideration of the Action Plan, which I recommend to the plenary vote tomorrow. I truly hope that Parliament’s cooperation with the Commission in the area of IPR enforcement will continue, in the interests of enhancing innovation, creativity and jobs growth for EU businesses and citizens.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: The debate has been closed. The vote will take place on Tuesday, 9 June 2015. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Rosa ESTARÀS FERRAGUT
text: in writing. – Intellectual property rights are one of the driving forces of innovation and creativity, and contribute essentially to competitiveness, employment and cultural diversity. Violations of intellectual property rights, including counterfeiting, harm growth, job creation, innovation and creativity. Respect for the law is critical to the predictability of legislation, and it is essential to find effective, proportionate and dissuasive means of respecting intellectual property rights at the cross-border level. I believe that civil procedures for the protection of intellectual property should be improved for the benefit of SMEs and all individual creators, as SMEs play a key role in the creative and cultural sectors. In this regard, I would like to ask the Commission for a strategy on intellectual property rights, including a comprehensive legal framework to combat infringements of intellectual property rights that is adapted to the internet environment, in full respect of fundamental rights and freedoms, the right to a fair trial, the principle of proportionality and data protection.

name: Lidia Joanna GERINGER DE OEDENBERG
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The enforcement of intellectual property rights (IPR) provides the basis for the growth of employment and the development of the Union and the proper functioning of the single market and many of the industries benefiting from such rights. It is also a major catalyst for innovation, creativity and competitiveness. As the European Commission points out, ipr-saturation sectors account for around 39% of EU GDP, or approximately EUR 4.7 billion per year, and offer up to 35% of all jobs. I therefore welcome the EU Action Plan on the Enforcement of Intellectual Property Rights, in particular by paying due attention to a targeted information campaign and enforcement of rights through a 'follow the money' approach, ensuring that the perpetrators of serious fraud in this area are punished by profiting from this illegal practice.  Nevertheless, it will be necessary to align the Commission's action on the enforcement of intellectual property rights with the development of the Digital Single Market, which is becoming the site of the main trade in counterfeit goods. In this context, online platform owners should be involved in enforcement issues and in efforts to exclude those responsible for infringements in the online trade in goods. It should be borne in mind that trade in counterfeit products not only causes a loss of income for businesses and the European economy, thereby leading to job losses, but also poses a threat to the health and safety of consumers.

name: Claudia SCHMIDT
text: Writing. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for his work and for the way in which Intellectual property protection has never been more important than it is today. Intellectual property is an essential driver of innovation and creativity. This is not just about copyright alone, but also about trademarks and patents of goods and services, which make a major contribution to Europe's competitiveness, growth, employment and also to Europe's cultural wealth. Alarming figures such as 36 million confiscated items in 2013 force us to act and act. For this reason, I warmly welcome both the EU Action Plan on Intellectual Property Rights and the report on a strategy for the protection and enforcement of intellectual property rights in third countries, which will be put to the vote in plenary on 9 June.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. 36 million counterfeit items were seized at European borders worth more than 760 million euros. These products violate intellectual property rights pose a threat to the health, safety of consumers, the environment and the economy. This traffic also steals the employment of 100,000 Europeans and strikes many SMEs. That is why Parliament voted today in favour of the European Action Plan against Counterfeiting and proposes some additional ways to combat fraud. In terms of numbers, the shortfall of 470 million euros per year and the 100,000 jobs prevented by this parallel economy give the scale of the problem. In 2013, 36 million items were seized, 10% of them medicines, as well as toys, food and cosmetics.  I would like to stress the crucial importance of involving all stakeholders involved in the subject of intellectual property in the development of possible future legislation: citizens, NGOs, artists, creators, SMEs, associations and not just multinationals, as was the case with the now defunct ACTA.
